problems.title: 0.1 Intro to CLUE
problems.subtitle: Working in the Collaborative Learning User Environment

text: CLUE is short for Collaborative Learning User Environment.
It has been designed to help you do math together with your classmates.

In CLUE, everyone works in a group with up to four people. When you start an activity, CLUE drops you into a group randomly. You can change groups by clicking on the group number in the upper right corner. Then, you can either join an existing group that has fewer than four students, or start a new group. Your teacher may ask you to join a specific group. When you change groups, your work moves with you.

Groups are important in CLUE. You can learn from classmates in your group and they can learn from you. Many features of CLUE are designed to help you share information and learn from others in your group and in your class.

This activity is designed to acquaint your students with the features of the CLUE platform. In the first two sections — Introduction and Initial Challenge — students get a chance to try out the features of their individual workspaces and the tools that are available for solving problems. The latter two sections — What If…? and Now What Do you Know? — present the collaboration tools, so students learn how to share their work with their group members and with the class.

To get the most out of this activity or any activity, seat students in groups of four, if possible, and have these students work in the same group. As students work, encourage them to share their questions and their findings and help each other. At the end, you may want to use student-published work to pull together the major discoveries that students have made about the CLUE platform.
Finally, CLUE has been developed for use with the Chrome browser, and we recommend using it. With other browsers, certain functions may work differently than described here.
Each problem has three or four parts. The tabs above display each part. Try clicking on the tabs listed below, then click back to the Introduction.

• Introduction
  • Initial Challenge
  • What If…?
  • Now What Do You Know?
(Note: Not all lessons have an Introduction.)
Problems are made of little chunks called tiles that contain the following:
Try hovering your mouse over the text or other features. You’ll see a gray box around each “tile.”
On the right is your workspace. To edit your workspace, you must first add a tile. You get a tile in your workspace by either

• Dragging a tile from the problem (on the left) or any other document into your workspace.
  • Dragging a new (empty) tile from the menu on the left of your workspace.

All tiles have a waffle (gray box with six dots) in the upper right corner if you hover over it. To drag the tile, click the waffle and hold it down as you drag it to your workspace. As you drag the tile into the workspace, a blue line shows where the tile will go when you let go.

Your workspace has dividers for each section of the problem. Put your answers in the same section as that of the question. For instance, drag the tile below into the Introduction section and try writing your own haiku below it.
(The usual haiku has three lines, a total of 17 syllables with lines of 5, 7, and 5 syllables.)

Drag the tiles that you need to help you answer the questions from the problem into the appropriate section of your workspace. Drag them around to arrange them as you like. Once a tile is in your workspace, you can edit it, delete it, or move it around. Use the tiles from the problem and the ones you add to describe how you arrived at your answers by showing your work along with the answers.

You can arrange the screen to show My Resources or My Workspace or to have the screen split. Hover over the three vertical dots on the divider between your Resources and your Workspace and click the arrows to change the screen. You can also close the Resources view by clicking the “X” on the upper right corner of the Resources panel.

tiles.title: Open and close Workspace and esources views

text: When your working session is over, just close the browser window. Your workspace is saved automatically. (There is no Save button.) If you are on a shared computer, be sure to log out of the STEM Resource Finder. Now, click the Initial Challenge tab to continue.

It’s time to try out each of CLUE’s tools. You’ll decide which tools to use to solve a problem. Knowing how the tools work will help you present your mathematical answers in a way that makes sense to you, whether that’s in words or a graph or table. To use a tool, just click it. You can then move it to a particular section or above or below another tile. Or to position it precisely, drag it from the toolbar into your workspace, moving to where you want it (the drop zone is indicated by a blue vertical bar), then let go.

tiles.title: Tool Tiles on the CLUE Toolbar

text: When you click into a text tile in your workspace, a tray with icons for editing options appears below it. Hover your mouse over the items in the tray for more information (and a keyboard shortcut) about each.
The text tool is like many other editors, but some options may work slightly differently.

1. To select text, click in the text tile, then drag over the text or use the arrow keys with the Shift key to select by character or Command-Shift for larger selections. (On a PC, use the Ctrl key instead of the Command key.) Note: Dragging where there is no text moves the whole text tile.
  2. To use an editing tool, select the text you want to format (e.g., bold, italicize, etc.), then click the tool, which will turn blue. Or click the tool first, and start typing formatted text. Be sure to click the tool again to deselect it when you’re done.
Drag this tile into the Initial Challenge section in your workspace, and format the text below as described.
A few more things about text tiles:
When text is selected, you can use the usual keyboard shortcuts:

• Cut: Command-X
  • Copy: Command-C
  • Paste: Command-V
  • Undo: Command-Z
  • Redo: Command-Shift-Z
  • Select all text in a tile: Command-A

Use a table to relate two or more quantities. Tables can hold numbers or text. You can edit the table title or column labels by double-clicking. You can move from cell to cell with the tab key. Below are some example tables. Drag each one into the Initial Challenge section and make the suggested edits.

Explore the table functions. See if you can add another column and label it Height (ft.), then fill the column with heights. You can make up the numbers (or research them, if you want). Also, add another dinosaur or two and fill out the columns with numbers.

Tables can help you see patterns. Here is a table that shows the number of ways points (not on a line) can be connected with straight lines. Put this in the Initial Challenge workspace and add a row or two. Can you continue the pattern for 6 and 7 points or more? Add a text tile to describe how you solved it.
Tables have other features that we’ll explore later in this activity.
The Graph tool allows you to work with both geometrical figures and number relationships on a graph. Many features are available from the graph tray that appears when a graph tile is selected.

Try out the geometrical features by dragging the Graph tile below into the Initial Challenge workspace. Drag this text tile in, too, and close out this panel (with the “X”) so you have more room to work. When you are done, click on My Resources and come back to the Initial Challenge.

1. Double-click one of the points A, B, or C. Double-clicking a point connects all unconnected points together in the order they were created.
  2. Click the middle of the triangle to select it. Now you can drag it around. When selected, there is a rotate icon. You can spin it.
  3. You can select any part of a geometric figure, a point, an edge, or the whole thing. Try selecting these things; they turn red or are highlighted. Once they are selected, you can move them around.
  4. Clicking on the graph creates a point. Make some points and then connect them into a shape.
  5. If a point, line, or shape is not quite where you want it, you can select it, and move it with the arrow keys on your keyboard.
  6. Select a shape and duplicate it. There are two ways to do so. Can you find them both?
  7. Change the name and the maximum or minimum values of the graph axes by clicking on the “x” or the “y.” You can give the axes labels, too.
You can try out the remaining features and some tricks with the Graph tool later in this activity.

Use the image tool to add a picture or snapshot to your work. For example, you might want to do some of your work with a pencil and paper. You can take a picture of it with the computer’s camera or a cell phone camera and upload it to your workspace. Then, all your work is together and your teacher can easily see it.

tiles.title: Snapshot of physical work loaded in CLUE

text: You can upload an image three ways: (1) Drag an image (JPG, PNG) from your computer directly into your workspace, (2) Drag and drop an image into a new image tool, or (3) Use the Upload Image option below the image tool to upload the file.
Of course, you can always drag an image from a problem into your workspace.
This simple draw tool can help you explain your answers when nothing else will. Drag a new Draw tool into the Initial Challenge workspace, and try it out.
There are several features in the Draw tray.

• Select - Every mark you make in the draw tool is a separate element. When the Select arrow is highlighted, just click on an element to select it. Then you can move it or delete it. Select multiple elements by dragging over them or clicking.
  • Freehand - Draw with the mouse. The color can be changed.
  • Line - Draw straight lines. The color can be changed.
  • Rectangle - Draw a four-sided figure. To get a perfect square, hold down the shift key when dragging.
  • Ellipse - Draw a round figure. To get a perfect circle, hold down the shift key when dragging.
  • Line/border color - Change the color of Freehand, Line, or the outlines of Rectangles or Ellipses.
  • Fill color - Change the color of the inside of Rectangles or Ellipses.
  • Delete - Delete the selected elements.
Note: In some activities, the Draw tool has an extra feature called Stamp with small icons you can use to solve the questions for that problem.
Using the Table and Graph Tool Together
The Table and Graph tools can be linked together. Try this:

1. Drag the table labeled Dog into your workspace.
  2. Drag a new graph next to it.
  3. Drag the Dog table on top of the graph.
  4. Double-click one of the points on the graph.

When the Dog table is linked to the Graph, and a point has been double-clicked, it will look like this. The label can be added by students. Linked graph points cannot be changed on the graph, but changed points on the table will be updated on the graph. Students will need to Select and Duplicate the dog to move it or change the shape of it.
Once you can see a dog, what can you do with it? Try selecting the whole figure and then different elements of it--points and lines. Then test the different tools in the graph tray. For instance,

1. What can you move with the mouse, and what won't move?
  2. Can you duplicate the figure (make a copy)?
  3. If you can make a copy, try doing things with the copy.
  4. Can you move it? Rotate it? Stretch it?
  5. Can you measure an angle using the graph tools?
  6. Can you measure a length of one segment?
See if you can unlink the graph. What happens?

The Graph tool can measure the lengths of line segments using the Segment Label feature. It also can be used to make measurements on images that can be uploaded to the graph. Start a new graph in the Initial Challenge section and find an image on your computer that you’d like to share. You can make points and shapes on top of the image. Is there anything in the image that you can measure? Add a label with a measurement.
CLUE is designed so that you can learn with others in your group and in your class. Discussing and sharing your work is an important part of the learning process.

Sharing your work with your group is controlled with the button and slider switch in the upper right corner of your workspace. The button on the left toggles your workspace view from your individual view to a group view. In the group view, your work is always in the upper left corner. You can see the initials of your group members in each window pane.

Once students get started with the mathematical activities, feel free to direct them in the use of sharing. Some teachers prefer students to work independently initially, and have students share their work with their group after their first attempts at problem-solving. For each student, sharing to the group is off by default, but it is controlled by the student. However, students who have trouble getting started often get a lift from their peers by seeing how others are tackling the problems. Think of group sharing as a tool that you can use flexibly by directing your students according to their needs.
The Share slider makes your work visible to your group members.
Your group members cannot change your work and you can’t change theirs. However, you can drag tiles from your group members’ workspaces and they can drag tiles from your workspace.

Switch to group view and turn on sharing. Ask your group members to do the same. You can zoom into each window by placing your cursor at the center of the four windows, and dragging the window panes to see more detail.
Look at your group members’ work in the Introduction. Did they write a haiku? In the Initial Challenge did they do something fun with the dog graph?

If you like something from your group members’ work, copy it by dragging your neighbor’s tile and placing it in your What if...? Section, for example. Then you can edit it and expand on it. Your neighbor may want to copy it back after your changes.

Why is this useful when doing math? Imagine that you’re working on a problem and your neighbor finds a different way to solve it. You can trade your solutions. Or, maybe you are stuck on how to start a problem. Perhaps your neighbors can help you get going.

To share your work with others in your class, publish it by clicking the button at the top left of your workspace. Others can find the published documents by clicking the Class Work tab. You may update your work by publishing it again. Only the most recent version is visible to your class.

To create new files for your personal use or to edit existing files, use the File dropdown menu. You might create files to try something out or take notes. Below are the things you can do. Try them out.

• Make a copy copies your present workspace. This copy is not shared with your group (there is no share icon while you are working on it). Give it a new name. It is your private copy, although you can publish it to the class.
  • Open allows you to create a new document by clicking the New Workspace icon. You can also access documents that are associated with the problem you are working on. The Workspaces tab shows your current problem document on top and any new documents that you may have created below the divider line. With the Learning Log tab you can create files that you can see and edit throughout the entire Unit. This is a good place to summarize your learning. The Starred tab shows documents that you may have highlighted as important from My Work or Class Work on the My Resources page.

This section shows students how they can use their past work or published class work to synthesize their learning. Students can access published work, either from other students or from you, and incorporate them into their documents.

Editing and updating the Learning Log is a particularly powerful way for students to reflect on their learning. Learning Log files are visible in each problem of the Unit. Encourage students to take notes on the Unit content and incorporate it into their Learning Logs.

So far, you have been only using the Problem tab on the left side of the screen. Now try using the three remaining tabs to access saved personal documents or class documents while editing another document on the right side of the screen. Explore the tabs to find a document and click the icon of the document. It will appear on the left. If you have a document on the right, you can drag tiles into it just as you would from the Problems tab. The files are sorted by the tabs:

• My Work holds your present workspace and any extra documents you may have created.
  • Class Work holds all published work from your teacher or from other students.
  • Supports are documents created by the lesson authors (Problem Supports) or your teacher (Teacher Supports) to enhance your learning.
Under My Work and Class Work, you also have access to sub-tabs:

• Learning Logs are documents that you can access throughout the Unit. They are designed for you to take notes and reflect on your learning over time. Your own Learning Logs are located under My Work and Learning Logs shared from other students in your class are under Class Work.
  • Starred documents are documents that you have highlighted as important and want to find easily. You can highlight any document by clicking on the light gray star on the document’s thumbnail icon.
  • Workspaces contain your present workspace document and any extra workspace that you may have created.

investigations.title: SAS Investigation 1 Enlarging and Reducing Shapes

problems.title: SAS 1.1 Solving a Mystery with Proportional Reasoning

text: The Mystery Club at P.I. Middle School meets monthly. Members watch videos, discuss novels, play “whodunit” games, and talk about real-life mysteries. One day, a member announces that the school is having a contest. A teacher in disguise will appear for a few minutes at school each day for a week. Any student can pay $1 for a guess at the identity of the mystery teacher. The student with the first correct guess wins a prize.
The Mystery Club decides to enter the contest together. Each member brings a camera to school in hopes of getting a picture of the mystery teacher.

One of Daphne’s photos looks like the picture below. Daphne has a copy of the P.I. Monthly magazine shown in the picture. The P.I. Monthly magazine is 10 inches high. She thinks the photo might be helpful in determining the height of the mystery teacher.

tiles.title: Daphne’s photo of the mystery teacher by a magazine rack

text: * Is Daphne's claim correct? Is it possible to use the magazine and the picture to estimate the teacher's height? Explain.

Daphne’s claim is correct. In her picture, we can measure both the height of the P.I. magazine and the height of the teacher and then compare two values. Knowing the P.I. magazine is 10 inches high in real life, you can estimate the teacher’s real height.

• Students can use rulers or edges of a piece of paper to make informal estimates of various measurements. Do not push for precise measurement at this time. Pay attention, though, to which students measure naturally and easily and which struggle with measurement. This will help you to plan your teaching in later Problems in the Unit where careful measurement is important.
  • Some students will measure the height in inches on the magazine and of the mystery teacher. They will then divide the height of the teacher by the height of the magazine to find how many magazines tall the teacher is. This is a more precise version of the first strategy. Make sure students are clear about the comparisons that they are making. They may compare the real magazine to the magazine in the picture or the magazine in the picture to the teacher in the picture.
  • The magazine is 10 inches tall. The teacher is about 7 magazines, or 70 inches, tall.
  • In the picture, the height of the P.I. Monthly is 0.5 in. We know that the height of the real magazine is 10 in. So, the real magazine is 10 ÷ 0.5=20 times larger than in the picture. The teacher should also be 20 times larger in real life than he/she is in the picture. The teacher’s height in the picture is about in. So, the actual height is about 20  =72.5 in.
  • Students may use ratio or “for every” statements, such as “The ratio of the teacher’s height in the picture to her height in real life is about 1 to 20.” Or “For every inch in height of the magazine in the picture there are 20 inches in height for the real magazine.”
  • Students may also compare the magazine in the picture to the teacher in the picture. In this case, the teacher is / = 7 times as tall as the magazine. Students may say that the teacher is 7 magazines tall. This should be true in real life as well. Since the height of the magazine is 10 in., the teacher is 10x7=72.5 in. tall.
* Could you find the height of the teacher if you did not know that the magazine was 10 inches tall? Explain.

• Yes. Instead of the height of the magazine, I could have measured the height of the actual bookshelf shown in the picture and used it to figure out the teacher’s height.
  • No. If I do not know the real height of the magazine is 10 inches, I would not be able to find the real height of the teacher. I only know the teacher is 7.25 times taller than the magazine.
Students will think about the proportional relationship of heights between the picture and the reality.
I used ratios to find the height of the teacher. For every inch measured of the PI magazine, there are 10 inches in real life. I used the PI magazine height to measure the height of the teacher.
How could ratios help her find the height of the teachers?
Every 1 magazine represents 10 inches, we can scale this ratio to find how tall the teacher is. For example:
? inches for every 7 magazines (if the teacher is 7 magazines tall in the picture)
1. How does the real-life teacher differ from the teacher in the photo?

The teacher in the photo is smaller than the real-life teacher. But the ratio between the height of the teacher in the photo and the height of the magazine in the photo is the same as the ratio between the height of the real-life teacher and the height of the real-life magazine.
If we cut the hat from the photo and put it on our head, it would be ridiculously small. We would need to scale-up the size of the hat to get it to fit.
2. Can you think of some other times you could use a photo to estimate the size of something?

* You might want to use a photograph to estimate the size of a large item you plan to buy, such as a large bookshelf. Estimating its size can help you determine whether or not it will fit in its designated spot.

* You could also take a close-up shot of something small, like an insect, next to an object with a standard size, like a penny. Then you can compare the features of the insect, such as its size, to pictures in a reference book.
The Mystery Club advisor says that the picture is similar to the actual scene. What do you suppose the advisor means by similar? How is the photo similar to the actual scene that is photographed?

By similar, the advisor might mean that the figures in the picture look the same as the original shapes in the actual scene, except in size. The photo represents the actual scene in real life in a smaller version.

As the introduction to the Unit, students might have general rather than mathematically specific answers. Students should begin to informally recognize that proportional relationships between quantities can be used to estimate the relationships between the lengths.

tiles.title: Did You Know?: Measurement in police work

text: Problem 1.1 Solving a Mystery with Proportional Reasoning

This Problem can be used to assess students’ initial ideas about the concept of scaled drawings/similarity. In the Initial Challenge, the P.I. Mystery Club enters a contest to guess the identity of a teacher in disguise. A photo of the mystery teacher is shown, and students use a known measure (height of a magazine) to estimate an unknown measure (height of the mystery teacher). In the What If Situations students are asked to express their informal ideas about the mathematical meaning of similarity.
The Mystery Club advisor says that the picture is similar to the actual scene. What do you suppose the advisor means by similar? How is the photo similar to the actual scene that is photographed?

Students began their work in proportional reasoning in 6th grade. They have used “for every” statements in many situations. Have them recall some of that work. Examples from Comparing Quantities: for every $3 the Washington students plan to raise the Central students plan to raise $1; for every 10 students who prefer cheese, five students prefer pepperoni; for every 30 Chewy Fruit worms it costs $30. In this Problem students will expand their thinking around “for every” statements using similar figures which are also called scale drawings or scale figures. This will lay a foundation for future work on proportional reasoning.
Display Learning Aid 1.1: Photograph of Mystery Teacher or have the students refer to their books.

• What information do we have?
  • What are we trying to find?
  • How does the real-life teacher differ from the teacher in the photo?
Be careful to leave the task of finding the teacher’s height open enough so that you can learn what your students think about similar figures.

Students can use rulers or edges of a piece of paper to make informal estimates of various measurements. Do not push for precise measurement at this time. Pay attention, though, to which students measure naturally and easily and which struggle with measurement. This will help you to plan your teaching in later Problems in the Unit where careful measurement is important.

Look for language such as ratio, rates, fractions, percentage, more than, or less than as students express their comparisons. In the Summarize you can come back to the comparisons and ask students to describe them using terms they learned in previous grades. This is a good assessment of what understanding students bring from Grade 6 about ratios, rational numbers and proportional reasoning.

Have students share their strategies and solutions on the height of the teacher. It is helpful for students to hear others’ ideas while they are developing their own. You should expect some variation in the answers because all measurements are approximations. However, answers that are obviously unreasonable should be examined closely and efforts should be made to figure out why they are incorrect.
Focus the summary conversations on the use of ratios, “for every” statements and measurement. Listen for the use of formal and informal language to assess your students’ understanding of these ideas.
• What measurements were important to you in finding the height of the teacher?
Discuss students’ perception of similar figures/scaled drawings. They might say things like, “look alike,” “same shape,” “same features,” “different size,”...

• Can you think of some other times when you might want to use a photograph to estimate the size of something?
  • In the movie theater, the image of the person on screen is taller than the real person. How can you use the same techniques to estimate someone’s height from their image on a movie screen?
  • Would you have been able to solve the problem had you not known the magazine was 10 inches tall?
  • Can someone explain Daphne’s statement: For every one magazine height, there are 10 inches in real life?
  • In What If Situation A, do you agree with Daphne’s reasoning?
As you finish the mathematical discussions, have students reflect on the Now What Do You Know question(s).

problems.title: SAS 1.2 Designing a Poster Using a Rubber Band Stretcher

text: In Problem 1.1 A, Daphne used ratio relationships to solve the mystery. She reasoned:

> _For every inch measured on the PI magazine, there are 10 inches of the PI magazine in real life. I used the PI magazine height to measure the height of the teacher. The teacher is 7 PI magazines tall. So, in real life the teacher is 7 x 10 inches or 70 inches tall._

Daphne’s reasoning is similar to the reasoning you have done in the _Comparing Quantities_ unit where you used ratios to describe and compare quantities. Recall that a **ratio** is a comparison of two quantities which have a multiplicative relationship, such as two lengths.
* 1 PI magazine height to the height of the teacher (7 PI magazines)
Using ratio relationships to solve problems is also called proportional reasoning.
Michelle, Daphne, and Mukesh are officers of the Mystery Club. Mukesh designs a flier to attract new members.

Daphne is making a large poster to publicize the next meeting. She wants to redraw the club’s logo, “Super Sleuth,” in a larger size. Michelle shows her a clever way to enlarge the figure by using rubber bands.
* Rubber bands – identical size, bands about 3 inches long work well
* Learning Aid – with a shape to enlarge and anchor point
* Make a “two-band stretcher” by tying the ends of the rubber bands together.
* Tape the Learning Aid to your desk. Next to it, tape a blank sheet of paper.
If you are right-handed, put the blank paper on the right.
If you are left-handed, put the blank paper on the left.

tiles.title: Left-handed and right-handed setup for using a rubber band stretcher

text: * With your finger, hold down one end of the rubber-band stretcher on point P. Point P is called the anchor point.
* Put a pencil in the other hand of the stretcher. Stretch the rubber bands with the pencil until the knot is on the outline of the shape.

* Keep the rubber bands taut (stretched). Move your pencil to guide the knot around the picture. Your pencil will draw a copy of the shape. The new picture is called the image of the original. It is also a scale drawing of the original.

* Use the rubber-band method to enlarge the figure on the Mystery Club flier. Draw the figure as carefully as you can, so you can compare the size and shape of the image to the size and shape of the original figure.

Note: Students will experience different levels of success using the rubber band to enlarge the shape. Have fun with it. The messy shapes motivate the need for more precise stretching and shrinking strategies that students will experience in the next few problems.
Technique Notes: It is important to keep the rubber band as close to the paper as possible. And, watch the knot, not your pencil.
* How are the original figure and its image alike? Different? What is your evidence?

Students may compare the general shapes of two figures, the lengths of line segments in the hats and bodies, the areas or the perimeters of the hats and bodies, the angles in the hats and bodies, or the distance of corresponding points on each figure from the anchor point P. Because the tool does provide exact replicas, the answers will be estimates at this time.

• The general shapes of the two figures are the same.
  • The angles in the image are the same as the corresponding angles in the original.
  • The lengths of the corresponding line segments are different. The lengths in the image seem to be twice as long as the corresponding lengths in the original.
  • The perimeters of the body and the hat in the image seem to be twice as long as those in the original. Students may reason that since each line segment doubles, the perimeter, which is the sum of these doubled line segments, will also double. (Doubling each side individually then finding the perimeter is the same as finding the perimeter and then doubling it. This is intuitively the Distributive Property: 2L + 2L + 2w + 2w = 2(L + L + w + w).)
  • The areas of the body and hat in the image seem to be 4 times as large as those in the original. Students may see that approximately 4 of the original rectangles (hats) can fit into the enlarged rectangle (hat). If students say the areas are three or four times as large, this is fine at this stage. The important idea is that the area is more than twice as large.
  • The distances of each figure from the anchor point P also have a 2 to 1 ratio. That is, each point on the image is twice the distance from P as the original corresponding point is from P.

Note that the answers above are true in the ideal case. In practice, the 2 to 1 ratio of the lengths (and the 4 to 1 ratio of the areas) will not always be observed. This is because of the imperfection of the bands and some differences in the application of the method. More precise methods will be explored in next Problems.

The rubber band stretcher results are more accurate if the end of the rubber band on point P is fixed by holding a pin instead of holding by hand directly; if the image end of the band is held as close to the page as possible using the pencil; if the pencil chosen is as thin as possible since its thickness might cause the band in the image end to be shorter than it is supposed to be; if the bands are not stretched too much.

supports.text: How do the lengths of line segments compare between the two figures?
How do the areas of the two figures compare?
How do the angles of the two figures compare?

text: Ms. Marvel’s class made several comparison statements about the original figure and the image.
Merve’s Comparison: The lengths of the sides of the image are twice the lengths of the original.
Ashley’s Comparison: The distance from a point on the original figure to anchor point P is equal to the distance from the image of the point to P.
Eli’s Comparison: The measure of an angle in the original figure has the same measure as the image of the angle.
Soro’s Comparison: The area of the hat of the original figure is about ¼ the area of the hat of image.
* Which of these statements are true? Explain your reasoning.
* Which of these statements represent ratios? Write these as ratio statements.
* Use your rubber band stretcher to enlarge another figure, such as a circle or square. Which of the comparisons are true for the original figure and its image?
* Any of these are ratios, see examples below:
* The same comparisons would be true for the original figure and its image.

Merve’s Comparison is true. We can place copies of the original lengths on the image to see this relationship. The ratio of original to image would be x to 2x. For every measurement in the original, the image is twice the size.
Any of the comparisons could be re-written as ratios. Examples include:
Merve’s Comparison: The comparison of the lengths on the image to the original is 2 to 1

Ashley’s Comparison is not true. The distance from the P to a point on the image is twice as long as the distance from the P to a point on the original. The distance between points on the image and original is equal to the distance between P to the original. A comparison statement that would be true might be: For every unit of measure going from P to the original, the image will have twice that distance.

Ashley’s Comparison: (Re-written to be true.) The distance from the point P to a point on the image is twice the distance from a point on the original. Or, the distance from the point P to the original compares to the distance from the point P the image by a ratio of 1 to 2.
Eli's Comparison is true. We can place copies of the original angles on the image to see this relationship. The angle ratios from the original to the image will always be 1 to 1.
Eli's Comparison: The measure of the angles have a 1 to 1 relationship. For every 90˚ on the original, there will be 90˚ on the corresponding angle of the image.
About 4 of the original hats fit inside the image hat. So, the original hat is about 1/4 the area of the image.
Soro's Comparison: The area of the hat of the original figure to the area of the hat of image is 1 to 4.
### Situation B. Changing the Anchor Point and Number of Bands
Several students had questions about the anchor point and the number of rubber bands. What is your response to each question?
DaShawn’s Question: What if we change the position of the anchor point? How does this affect the image?
Sunyoung’s Question: What if we use three rubber bands? We would still trace the figure using the knot closest to the anchor point. How will this affect the image?

Amy’s Question: The rubber bands seem to be acting like multipliers. Since there is a multiplying effect, we can use ratios. How can I use ratio language to describe what happens to corresponding side lengths?
If the location of P is changed, the location of the image will also change. However, the location of P does not affect the size or shape of the image.

For example, the darker blue triangle below is the original. Moving the location of P moves the image (lighter blue triangle). It does not change the shape or size. The length of the distances away from P remain proportional. If we look at corresponding right angles, on the image the right angle is always twice the distance from P while the right angle on the original is always one distance away from P.

tiles.title: Results of moving the anchor point for a rubber band stretcher

text: Note that there are two possible interpretations of Sunyoung’s question. Most students will use the knot closer to the anchor point to trace the original figure. Some students may use the knot closer to the pencil.
Answers for the knots closer to the anchor point:

• The shapes are similar to each other.
  • The lengths in the image figure are about 3 times as long as the lengths in the original figure.

tiles.title: Side lengths for similar figures from a three rubber band stretcher (knot closer to anchor point)

text:
• The areas in the image figure are about 9 times as big as the areas in the original figure.
  • Each point on the image is about 3 times as far from P as its corresponding point on the original figure.

tiles.title: Areas for similar figures from a three rubber band stretcher (knot closer to anchor point)

text: • Answers for the knots closer to the pencil:

tiles.title: Side lengths for similar figures from a three rubber band stretcher (knot closer to pencil)

text:
• The shapes are similar to each other.
  • The lengths in the image figure are about 1.5 times as long as the lengths in the original figure.

tiles.title: Areas of similar figures from a three rubber band stretcher (knot closer to pencil)

text:
• The areas in the image figure are about 2.25 times as big as the areas in the original figure. Students may estimate and say that the areas in the image are a little more than twice those in the original.
  • Each point on the image is about 1.5 times as far from P as its corresponding point on the original figure.

In Amy's Question, if the distances of each figure from the anchor point P have a 2 to 1 ratio, like the 2 rubber band stretcher, then the side length of the image figure is 2 times the side length of the original figure.
Using three rubber bands the ratio of the side length in figure 1 to the side length of corresponding side length in the image is 1 to 3 or 1 : 3.
The original figure and its image are similar figures or scale drawings. For two similar figures, what characteristics and measures are the same? Different? Explain how you know.
Informally students should see that when enlarging a geometric figure some attributes of shape change and some stay the same:

• angles of the two figures appear to be the same,
  • side lengths of the enlarged figure are longer,
  • area of the enlarged figure is bigger.
Note that as the Unit continues, students will revisit these questions and add more specific mathematical detail to them.

supports.text: Have you considered how points, angles, side lengths, and area change?

text: Problem 1.2 Designing a Poster Using a Rubber Band Stretcher

The Problem begins in the Initial Challenge with the Mystery Club enlarging a flier into a poster to attract new members. In this context, students create a similar figure using rubber bands. They make a stretcher by tying two rubber bands together and use it to enlarge two different figures. In the What If Situations they compare how the general shape, line lengths, areas, perimeters, and angles are affected. This focuses students’ attention on the preservation of shape in similar figures.
The original figure and its image are similar figures or scale drawings. For two similar figures, what characteristics and measures are the same? Different? Explain how you know.

In launching this Problem, your goal is to understand what your students intuitively know about scaled drawings or similar figures. Students’ understanding will likely be based on the use of “similarity” in everyday situations. In addition, you will want to assess their measurement skills.

Members of the Mystery Club want to make a poster that shows their logo. To do this, they need to enlarge the logo on the flier they designed. Briefly discuss with students the desire to make a larger version of the original picture. Then tell them that you are going to demonstrate one method for doing so.
You will need to demonstrate how to draw a figure using a rubber band stretcher, using a marker either on the board or on chart paper taped to the wall.
As students work, suggest that their drawings will be more accurate if they hold the pencil vertically and keep the rubber band as close to the point of the pencil as possible.

Remind students to trace the figure they are trying to copy with the knot, as they may be tempted to draw the object freehand. Accuracy is not the issue here, but students can get better drawings by being careful with the placement of the rubber bands on the pencil and the path of the knot on the figure

• What would happen if I made a three-band stretcher?
  • Do I get exactly the same drawing if I switch the ends of my two-band stretcher?
• How could we use something like the rubber band stretcher to make an image smaller than the original?

As you are observing students working with the rubber band stretchers and comparing their drawings to the originals listen to how they are describing them. Students will worry about the drawing being “perfect”. Help them to focus on the mathematical changes from the original shape to the image they are creating. How do they describe the change in the lengths of the line segments? The areas? Have they noticed that the angle measures stay the same? Take note of students who have ways to describe what has changed and what has stayed the same so you can have them share this in the Summary discussion.
Have students share their findings about the image of the new figure as compared to the original figure.
The Summary needs to focus students onto the mathematics around the use of the rubber band stretcher.

• How do the lengths of the line segments compare between the two figures?
  • How do the angles of the two figures compare?
  • Which comparison statements in What If Situation A can be written as ratio statements?
  • How does the area change from the original to the image?
  • The original and the image are similar figures. What do you think “mathematically similar” means?
As you finish the mathematical discussions, have students reflect on the Now What Do You Know question(s).

Note: The students measurements won’t be exact because the rubber band stretcher isn’t an exact tool. You may need to take a few measurements from students and then say something like, “It looks like the general shape of Super Sleuth is about the same. We are all getting the side lengths to about double, the angles seem to stay the same, the perimeter seems to about double and the area seems to do more than double.”

problems.title: SAS 1.3 Scaling Up and Down with Percents

text: In the last Problem, we worked with images, or scale drawings, that were similar to the original. Those scale drawings were larger than the original figure. In this Problem, you will work with scale drawings that are smaller than the original. You will also learn more about what it means for figures to be similar.

When we study similar figures, we often compare their sides and angles. Recall that to compare the parts correctly, mathematicians use the terms corresponding sides and corresponding angles. In every pair of similar figures, each side of one figure has a corresponding side in the other figure. Also, each angle has a corresponding angle.
The example below shows the corresponding sides and corresponding angles of two triangles.

tiles.title: Corresponding sides and corresponding angles for similar triangles ABC and DEF

text: There are different ways to identify angles. We can identify an angle with three letters. The letter identifying the vertex of an angle is always the middle letter in its name. We use the word ‘angle’ or the angle symbol ‘∠’. Also, we can also name an angle by its vertex when it is clear which angle we are referring to.

tiles.title: Names of angles in triangle ABCF

text: What names would you give the angles in the large triangle?
Name the corresponding angles in the following two similar triangles?

tiles.title: Similar triangles with an unknown side length

text: Daphne thinks the rubber-band method is clever, but she believes the school copier can make more accurate copies in a greater variety of sizes. She makes a copy of “Super Sleuth” with two different percent size factors. The results are shown below.

tiles.title: Copies of Super Sleuth with different percent size factors.

text: * What percent size multiplier did Daphne use to create Copy 1 and Copy 2? Explain your reasoning.

For Copy 2, if we compare corresponding sides such as the base of the triangle, 1 and ½ lengths of the original make the corresponding length of the copy. This means that the multiplier is 1.5 or 150% of the original.

tiles.title: Comparing side lengths for Super Sleuth and Copy 2

text: For Copy 1, if we compare corresponding sides such as the base of the triangle, ¾ of the length of the original makes the corresponding length of the copy. This means that the multiplier is 0.75 or 75% of the original.

tiles.title: Comparing side lengths for Super Sleuth and Copy 1

text: * How are the copies like the original? How are they different?

• Copy 1 are ¾ the size of the corresponding side lengths in the original
  • Copy 2 are 1.5 times the size of the corresponding side lengths in the original

Perimeter changes in the same way the corresponding side lengths change. This can be explained by the Distributive Property: For example, in Copy 2 the sides of the hat change b6 150%, so the perimeter will also change by 150%: 1.5l+1.5l+1.5w+1.5w=1.5(l+l+w+w)

• It’s smaller from the original to Copy 1
  • It’s larger from the original to Copy 2, but it is not 1.5 times larger.

Note: At this time in the Unit, students will make general statements about the area. Such as, “The area grows (or shrinks) but not in the same way as the lengths.” The area change relationship in scale figures will be developed in Investigations 2 and 3.

• The ratio in length from the original to Copy 1 is 1 to ¾.
  • The ratio in length from the original to Copy 2 is 1 to 1.5
Situation A. Changing Percents What if we wanted to create an image whose side lengths were twice the length of the original? What percent setting should we choose on the copier?

To increase a figure’s size by twice the length, you would want to make each side length 2 times as long as the side length of the original. The percent setting of 200% on the copier would make the side length of image 2 times longer than in the original.
The copier creates images that are similar to those made with the rubber band stretchers and the photograph. Do you agree? Explain why or why not.
Agree. The copier creates a more accurate image, but the relationships stay the same.

When you want to create an image twice bigger than the original, you would use two rubber bands. You can also use the copier with 200% percent setting. If you want to make an image three times bigger than the original, you would use three rubber bands. It is the same as when you use the copier with 300% percent setting. You can use both the rubber bands and the copier when you want to make a similar image.
For similar figures, what features (attributes) and measures stay the same? What features (attributes) and measures change? How does a multiplier play a role in these changes?

The shape will remain the same except in size. The measures of corresponding angles will also remain the same. Each corresponding length in the image will stretch or shrink by the multiplier. The areas seem to change in some predictable pattern.
Problem 1.3 Scaling Up and Down with Percents

In this Problem, using the context of a copy machine, students work with figures of various sizes that are similar to an original figure. They will work with some scale drawings that are smaller than the original figure and some that are larger. They will use percents to compare similar figures. In the What If Situations they will compare side lengths and angles of similar figures and notice that lengths of sides may differ, but the measures of angles do not.
For similar figures, what features (attributes) and measures stay the same? What features (attributes) and measures change? How does a multiplier play a role in these changes?

Connecting back to the sixth-grade rational number Units, students explore scale factors of 75% and 150%. During the discussions in Problem 1.2 you may have already introduced the term corresponding to talk about corresponding sides and angles of shapes. If you haven’t, use the Introduction to Problem 1.3 prior to presenting the challenge.
Set up the photocopier context by talking with students about the rubber-band stretchers and other methods for enlarging figures.

• If you wanted to make a very accurate enlargement of a figure, would you use a rubber-band stretcher?
  • What are some other ways to make a larger copy of something?

Project Learning Aid 1.3: Super Sleuth Figure and Two Copies to do a quick review of basic percent concepts. Cover up the captions under each figure. Tell students that the middle figure is the original.
• Estimate the percent Daphne entered into the photocopier in order to get the smaller image on the left.

Pay attention to how well your students are measuring. This is the first Problem in this Unit where more precision really makes sense, yet the comparisons are still relatively simple. Use this time to have students practice this important skill. Depending on how comfortable your students are with measuring, they may use rulers or transparent grid paper to measure side lengths; they may use angle rulers or protractors to measure angles.
If needed, this is also an opportunity to review operations with percents.

• What is the measurement of the base of the triangle in the smaller figure?
  • How could you use a rubber band stretcher to increase something by 150%?
Look for strategies that students use to compare features such as length and angles.

As you are circulating, listen for how students are answering the questions in the What If part? How are they describing the changes in the side lengths, area, and perimeter? Listen for their use of “for every” statements that you can expand on in the Summary
Ask students to explain their reasoning. This will give you insight into their understanding of percent. Be sure to discuss angle measures and side lengths.

Students may use addition strategies rather than multiplying by a scale factor. For example, they may divide the side lengths of the original figure by four equal segments and then subtract one of the segments to get the side length of the figure that has been reduced to 75%. To get the side length of the figure that is increased to 150% students may divide the side lengths of the original figure into two equal segments and then add one of the segments to the original.

• How did you describe the comparison between the corresponding side lengths?
  • To help students think about these ideas with a multiplicative structure versus additive you could ask them if there is a way to use a “for every” statement to express their idea.
  • If I want to enlarge a figure by 25% will the image be larger or smaller than the original? What number do I enter in the photocopier? Explain why this is true.
As you finish the mathematical discussions, have students reflect on the Now What Do You Know question(s).

investigations.title: SAS Investigation 2 The Mug Wump Family: Similar Figures

text: The Computer Club at P.I. Middle School also meets monthly. Zack and Marta suggested that the club design a computer game that involves several animated characters. They ask Marta’s uncle Carlos, a programmer for a video game company, about computer animation.

Carlos explains that the computer screen can be thought of as a grid made up of thousands of tiny points, called pixels. To animate a figure, we need to enter the coordinates of key points on the figure. The computer uses these points to draw the figure in different positions.

Sometimes the figures in a computer game need to change size. A change in the programming code can make a figure larger or smaller. We can code a rule for finding key points from the original figure. In this Investigation, we will explore answers to these questions.
Do the rules create scale drawings? That is, are the two figures similar?
The following problems will help us answer these questions

Zack and Marta experiment with enlarging and reducing figures on a coordinate grid. First, Zack draws Mug Wump on graph paper. Then he labels the key points from A to X and lists the coordinates for each point. Marta writes the rules that will change Mug’s size. Marta tries several rules for transforming Mug into different sizes. She wonders which rules will make family members that have similar shapes.
* Table of Coordinates for the Wump Game Characters
* First Quadrant Grids to plot the Wump Characters/Digital graph

* Plot Mug – Use the coordinate pairs in the “Mug Wump” column to draw Mug on grid paper. For Parts 1-3 of the figure, plot the points in order. Connect them as you go along. For Part 4, plot the two points, but do not connect them.

* Find Coordinates for the other Wump characters – Use the given rules to find the new coordinates for each shape. Record the coordinates in the columns Zug, Lug, Bug, and Glug. For example, the rule for Zug is (2x, 2y). This means that you multiply each of Mug’s coordinates by 2. Point A on Mug is (0, 1), so the corresponding point A on Zug is (0, 2). Point B on Mug is (2, 1), so the corresponding point B on Zug is (4, 2).
* Plot the other Wump characters – Plot and connect the points from A to X for each Wump character, just as you did for Mug. Put each shape on separate axes.
Mug Wump: (x, y), Zug: (2x, 2y), Lug: (3x, y), Bug: (3x, 3y), Glug: (x, 3y)
* Look at the figures created by Marta’s rules. Which family members are similar to Mug? Which figures appear not to be similar, and thus “imposters”? How do you know?

Zug and Bug are bigger versions of and have the same shape as Mug, so they are the other Wumps. From Mug to Zug and Bug, the angles and the general shape stayed the same. From Mug to Zug, the lengths doubled and from Mug to Bug, the lengths tripled.

On the other hand, Lug is too wide, and Glug is too tall to be the Wumps family. From Mug to Lug and Glug, corresponding lengths did not grow by the same factor. Lug is the same height as Mug but three times as wide. Lug is stretched on the x-axis values, but not the y-axis values. Glug is the same width as Mug but three times as tall. Glug is stretched on the y-axis values, but not the x-axis values. Many of Lug’s and Glug’s angles differ from Mug’s. So, Lug and Glug are impostors.

supports.text: What features are the same about Mug and the others? What features are different?
What features do you consider when you decide two figures are similar or not?

text:
Situation A. Student Claims

Below are claims made by Marta and her classmates. Is each Claim true? Explain why.
Marta’s Claim The rule (5x, 5y) will make a character that is similar to Mug, but the rule (5x, y) will not produce a character similar to Mug.

True. Like the rule (2x, 2y) makes Zug similar to Mug and the rule (3x, 3y) makes Bug similar to Mug, the rule (5x, 5y) also makes it similar to Mug. It will be 5 times wider and 5 times taller than Mug.
Jacob’s Claim I can use the coordinate rule to predict how the side lengths compare between Mug and a similar Wump. Is he correct?

Yes, this is true. With the rule (2x, 2y), Zug has double the side lengths of the corresponding side lengths of Mug’s. Also, with the rule (3x, 3y), Bug has triple the side lengths of the corresponding side lengths of Mug’s. Using the multiplier, you can predict how many times bigger (or smaller) the lengths on a similar figure are compared to the original lengths.
Zack’s Claim For similar figures, the corresponding angle measures change the same way as the corresponding side lengths.
False. The angle measures do not change from the original to the corresponding angles on the image.
Billie’s Claim The rule (x, y) creates a figure that is exactly the same as the original.

True. The multiplier is 1, since (x, y) = (1x, 1y). Multiplying any quantity by 1 is the multiplicative identity. The values of the coordinates will stay the same. So, the figure is like the identity; it will be the same size and shape.
1.  Make a rule that would create a figure similar to Lug.
2. Describe how the corresponding angle measures and side lengths change.

Angle measure will stay the same from one corresponding angle to another. Corresponding side lengths from the original to the image will get larger or smaller by the amount of the multiplier. For example, from Lug to the shape made with (6x, 2y), all of the lengths will double. From Lug to the shape made with (9x, 3y), all of the lengths will triple.

How can you determine if an original figure and its image are similar by looking at the coordinate rule that produced the image? What features (attributes) stay the same for Mug and similar figures? What features change?
Students should discuss enlarging geometric figures using coordinate grids and rules that produce both similar and non-similar figures.

If the coordinates for the original figure is (x, y), then the coordinates for the similar image is (kx, ky), which means that each x-coordinate and y- coordinate for the similar image is multiplied by the same number k to the original coordinates.
Also, students should expand understanding which attributes change and which stay the same:
* corresponding angles of two similar figures are the same measure while angles of non-similar figures may not be.
* corresponding side lengths from the original shape to the similar figure increase by the multiplier used to create a new rule.

tiles.title: Did You Know?: Images in computer graphics

text: In this Problem students learn how to make similar and non-similar shapes using a coordinate system. In the Initial Challenge students graph members of the Wump family, plus other figures that claim to be in the Wump family. Students will notice that members of the Wump family are similar to one another and the imposters are not similar. In the What If Situations students will focus on finding that corresponding angles are not congruent, and that corresponding side lengths are not multiplied by the same factor. They will also identify the type of rules that create similar shapes.

How can you determine if an original figure and its image are similar by looking at the coordinate rule that produced the image? What features (attributes) stay the same for Mug and similar figures? What features change?
Four choices of grids with one, two, or six grids on a Learning Aid (larger grids may provide accessibility for some students)
If your students need to review graphing, you might introduce them to tic-tac-toe on a 4 × 4 board, such as Teaching Aid 2.1A: 4-by 4- Board.
In this Problem, students create similar and non-similar figures using a coordinate system.
Students may need help in drawing Mug Wump because the points are used in sets that are connected in order.

• The rule is (2x, 2y). What do you think this rule tells us to do to a Mug point to get a Zug point?
  • What do the other rules tell you to do for Lug, Bug, and Glug?

As students are working, their figures should look roughly like Mug Wump. Ask students if their new characters generally look like Mug as a quick check to see if they are plotting the points correctly. Be careful to avoid using the word similar as this has a particular mathematical meaning, especially in this Problem.

• To create the coordinates for Zug, what must you multiply the coordinates of Mug by?
  • Describe the shape of Mug.
  • What measures help you identify the imposters?
  • What features are the same about Mug and the others?
  • What features are different?

Listen for the way students are deciding on the imposters. Take notes on groups that are using ratios, “for every” statements, etc. to describe the figures that are scaled drawings of Mug. Listen for students finding relationships between both dimensions with the figures that are similar. Listen for students describing that Mug, Bug, and Zug have congruent corresponding angles and that Zug and Glug do not.

It is very helpful to display copies of the figures for the class to view. You can use Learning Aid 2.1B: Grids, Teaching Aid 2.1B: Wump Characters, and Teaching Aid 2.1C: Wump Characters on Grids or student work.

• How would you describe to a friend the growth of the figures that you drew?
  • Which figures seem to belong to the Wump family and which do not?

• Which characters are imposters? How do you know?
  • How do the corresponding angles of the five figures compare
  • Are the lengths related? Are some of them related and others not? How do the lengths in similar Wumps compare?
  • Are the perimeters related? Are some of them related and others not? How do the perimeters in similar Wumps compare?
  • Could you use ratios or “for every” statements to describe the characters that are similar to Mug?
  • For What If Situation A, which claims are correct? Why?
  • What are some rules you could use to create a figure similar to Lug in What If Situation B?
As you finish the mathematical discussions, have students reflect on the Now What Do You Know question(s).

problems.title: SAS 2.2 Hats Off to the Wumps
problems.subtitle: Changing a Figure's Size and Location

text: Zack experiments with multiplying Mug’s coordinates by different whole numbers to make other characters. Marta asks her uncle how multiplying the coordinates by a decimal or adding numbers to or subtracting numbers from each coordinate will affect Mug’s shape. He gives her a sketch for a new shape (a hat for Mug) and some rules to investigate.
* Look at each rule and predict what will happen to the hat with each rule.

Students’ predictions will vary. At this time, many students may not have connected the stretching and shrinking to a multiplicative relationship. They may predict that adding will make a shape enlarge and subtracting will make a shape shrink. If so, students may predict that Hat 1 and Hat 5 will look the same.
* Test each rule. How does your result compare with your prediction?
Answers will vary. Predictions may or may not have matched what happened to the shapes.
* Hat 1 will move 2 units to the right and 3 units up without changing its size or shape. (congruent and similar)
* Hat 2 will move 1 unit left and 4 units up, also without changing its size or shape. (congruent and similar)
* Hat 3 will be located 2 units to the right, and it will be 3 times as high (stretched vertically and not similar)
* Hat 4 will shrink vertically and horizontally by the same factor: 0.5. It keeps the same shape. Each length will be half of the original corresponding length. (similar)
* Hat 5 will be stretched vertically by the factor of 2, and horizontally by the factor of 3. (not similar)

* Hats 1, 2, and 4 are similar to Mug’s Hat. Hat 1 and Hat 2 are the same size and shape as Mug’s hat, but they move to different place on the coordinate graph. Hat 4 has the same shape, but different size from the Mug’s hat.

supports.text: To predict what will happen to the hat with rules, recall the relationship between the rules to draw Zug, Lug, Bug, and Glug and its similarity in Problem 2.1.
In Problem 2.1, how is a rule with adding or subtracting a number to the x or y coordinate different from a rule with multiplying a number?

text: ### Situation A. Writing New Hat Rules
Several members of the computer club wrote different design criteria that would produce hats similar to the original Mug hat.
What rule would you write for each design?
**Syrah’s Design:** The side lengths are one third as long as Mug’s hat?
**Joe’s Design:** The side lengths are 1.5 times as long as Mug’s hat?
**Viola’s Design:**The hat is the same size as Mug’s hat but has moved right 1 unit and up 5 units?
**Kathy's Design:** The image is in another quadrant of the graph?
To move the image to the second quadrant, you should move it left more than 9 units and up more than 0: possible answers are (x-9, y), (x-10, y+1), (x-12, y+3).
To move the image to the third quadrant, you should move it left more than 9 units and down more than 3 units: possible answers are (x-9, y-3), (x-9, y-4), (x-11, y-4).
To move the image to the fourth quadrant, you should move it down more than 3 units and right more than 0 units: possible answers are (x, y-3), (x, y-5), (x+2, y-5).
Situation B. Raymond's Claim about Negative Numbers and Rules
If you multiply each coordinate by a negative number the image is similar but smaller. Is he correct? Explain.

If you multiply each coordinate (x, y) by -1 so you get (-x, -y), then the image has the same size of the original, but it rotates 180 deg as if x-axis and y-axis are used as mirrors. Students may multiply -1 to each coordinate of Mug’s and draw it as an example to see how the image looks like. This new Negative Hat will be in quadrant 3.
Situation C. Isaiah’s Challenge: Putting the Hat on Mug
I think it is possible to write a rule that will put Mug’s hat on Mug. My group will work on finding the correct rule.

It is possible. Because you can move the hat upwards on the coordinate plane by adding numbers to the y-coordinate, you can put the hat on Mug. One possible rule for a hat that student can come up with is (x-1, y+6). Students might struggle with making a rule for the move at first. Students can first draw the hat on Mug and make a table for the coordinates of moved hat. Then they can compare the coordinates of the original (points A, B, …, G) with the new coordinates. For the corresponding coordinates, students may count units that moves from the original position to the new position.

supports.text: What made the hat get smaller?
How did adding to the coordinates change the hat?
What did subtracting do to the hat?

text: If you know the coordinate rules to create an image, how can you tell if the two figures are similar? How can you use the rule to predict the side lengths of the image? How is the effect of a coordinate rule like the effect of a rubber band stretcher or a copy machine setting?

For the coordinates (x, y) of the original figure, if you make the coordinate rules by multiplying each coordinate by the same number, k, then the new image with the coordinates (kx, ky) is similar to the original figure. For example, if you multiply (x, y) by 2, then you will have new coordinates (2x, 2y). It makes the side lengths of the new image 2 times longer than the side lengths of the original figure. This rule has the same effect as both a rubber band with two-band stretcher and a copy machine setting with 200%.

You can use the rule to predict what will happen to the lengths of corresponding sides. When looking at the coordinate rules, the multiplier from one coordinate to the next will tell how much the side lengths change from one figure to another. For example, if we think of Zug as the original and Bug as the image, each coordinate in the rule multiplies by 1.5. So, the lengths of Zug will grow 1.5 times to make the lengths of Bug. Zug’s nose is 2 units tall and Bug’s nose is 2 • 1.5 = 3 units tall. Zug’s forehead is 8 units long and Bug’s forehead is 8 • 1.5 = 12 units long

tiles.title: Comparing nose lengths for Zug and Bug

text: Problem 2.2 Hats Off to the Wumps: Changing a Figure’s Size and Location

In this Problem, students investigate the effects that various algebraic rules have on Mug’s hat. In the Initial Challenge students explore what happens to the location of the hat when numbers are added to or subtracted from each coordinate versus when they are multiplied which changes the size of the hat. In the What If Situations they will be able to distinguish rules that produce similar figures from rules that do not produce similar figures, recognizing the role that multiplication plays in scaled drawings or similarity relationships.

If you know the coordinate rules to create an image, how can you tell if the two figures are similar? How can you use the rule to predict the side lengths of the image? How is the effect of a coordinate rule like the effect of a rubber band stretcher or a copy machine setting?
Tell the students that this Problem is related to drawing the Wump family and imposters. In this case they are looking at hats for the Wump family.

Drawing the hats in the Initial Challenge can be time consuming. During the What If you could have students do one of the situations and then have groups share the findings during the summary conversation.

Have students look at the table and the grids that are provided. They should have little trouble drawing the figures. However, it is important that the students start the Problem knowing that the main point of the Problem is to look back over their drawings and make sense of what adding or multiplying in the rule does to the image.
You might have students draw two or more hats on the same grid. If students use a different color for each hat, it will be easier to differentiate the images.

• What does the rule tell you that you need to do to the x coordinate? y coordinate?
  • Does adding a number to or subtracting a number from x or y coordinate make a difference?
  • What rule would give the largest possible image on the grids provided?
  • Make up a rule that would place the image in another quadrant.

As you are circulating during the Explore look for how students are connecting the rules to the hats they are creating. Look for students who can explain the effect of fractional coefficients and adding/subtracting to the x or y coordinate. Select students/groups to explain how to move figures, enlarge figures, or shrink figures on a grid using rules.
Ask students what happened with each of the rules.
• Are the images similar to the original? Why or why not?
Teaching Aid 2.2: Wump Hats on Grids or student work can be used during the discussions

• How did adding/subtracting to the coordinates change the hat?
  • Do adding and subtracting change a figure in the same way that multiplication changed Mug in Problem 2.1?
  • What rule made a hat get smaller? Why?
  • How can you tell if two rectangles (or triangles) are similar? What information should you collect?
  • What rule would make a hat with line segments 1/3 the length of Hat 1’s line segments?
  • What rule would make a hat the same size as Hat 1 but moved up 2 units on the grid?
  • Describe a rule that moves Hat 1 and does not produce a similar figure.
  • What are the effects of multiplying each coordinate by a number?
  • What effect does the rule (5x - 5, 5y + 5) have on the original hat?
  • Make up a rule that will shrink the figure, keep it similar, and then move it to the right and up.
  • Describe how to transform Hats 1–5 back to Mug’s Hat.
As you finish the mathematical discussions, have students reflect on the Now What Do You Know question(s).

problems.title: SAS 2.3 Mouthing Off and Nosing Around
problems.subtitle: Scale Factors

text: In the computer game the characters were members of the Wump family. We found a way to decide which characters were imposters using the coordinate rule.

tiles.title: Character animations for the Wumps and imposters

text: How can you decide whether two shapes are similar?

We have experimented with rubber-band stretchers, copiers, and coordinate plots. Your experiments suggest that for two figures to be similar, there must be the following correspondence between the figures:
  • Corresponding angles are the same size
  • The side lengths of one figure are multiplied by the same number to get the corresponding side lengths in the second figure.

The scale factor is the number that the side lengths of one figure are multiplied by to give the corresponding side lengths of a similar figure.
  • What is the multiplier or scale factor when you use two rubber bands to enlarge a figure?
  • What is the multiplier or scale factor when you use a copier setting of 150%? 75%?
The diagram shows a collection of mouths (rectangles) and noses (triangles). Some are from the Wump family. Others are from impostors.
* Identify pairs of similar shapes. Provide evidence that your shapes are similar. What is the scale factor?

Rectangles (mouths) J, L, and N are similar to each other. Students should point out that since these are all rectangles, the angles are all right angles and hence congruent, or the same size. For rectangles, it is then only necessary to check side lengths.
L to J is 2; L to N is 3; J to N is 3/2
J to L is 1/2 (reciprocal of 2); N to L is 1/3 (reciprocal of 3); N to J is 2/3 (reciprocal of 3/2 ).
Triangles (noses) O, R, and S are similar to each other.
O to R is 2; O to S is 3; and R to S is 3/2 .
R to O is 1/2 (reciprocal of 2); S to O is 1/3 (reciprocal of 3); S to R is 2/3 (reciprocal of 3/2 ).
• In what ways could scale factor be useful when determining similar figures?

The scale factor tells us how much the new figure has been stretched or shrunk in both vertical and horizontal directions. If the scale factor is larger than 1, then the new figure will be bigger than the original figure. The new side lengths and perimeters will be the scale factor times as large. If the scale factor is less than 1, then the new figure will be smaller than the original figure. The new side lengths and perimeters will be the scale factor times as small.

supports.text: When you identify pairs of rectangles or triangles, what measurements do you compare? Angles, Side lengths, Perimeters, Areas, etc.

text: Marta and her Friends make claims. For each claim, decide if it is correct? Explain why.

Marta and Zack agree that rectangles J and L are similar. Marta says the lengths are growing by a factor of 2. Billie claims the lengths grow by 200%. Zack says the scale factor is ½.  Zack says the scale factor is ½. Who is correct?
All are correct. Rectangles J and L are similar because each corresponding side length has the same ratio.
If you multiply ½ to each side length of rectangle J, then you will get rectangle L that is similar to J. In this way, the scale factor is ½.
If you multiply 2 to each side length of rectangle L, then you will get rectangle J that is similar to L. In this way, the scale factor is 2.
A scale factor is 2 is the same as growing by 200%.

To determine if two rectangles are similar, I can use ratios to show that the scale factor is the same for corresponding side lengths. For example, if the ratio of original side to corresponding side in two similar rectangles is 3 units for every 4 units, then the scale factor from the original to similar rectangle is ¾.

Not correct. To increase an original side of 3 to a corresponding side of 4, ou would use a multiplier of 1 ⅓. The scale factor is the same as the multiplier. So, the scale factor is 1 ⅓, not 3/4 as Mia thought.
To find the multiplier, you can use the relationship between the sides. You can scale the ratio of the sides to a unit rate.
For every 3 units on the original there are 4 units on the image.
So, for every 1 unit on the original there are 1 ⅓ units on the image.
Note that students have often found it easier to think of the scale factor as a multiplier rather than a ratio.
Jacob's Claim I think that if two triangles are similar, you can use ratios to show that the scale factor is the same for corresponding sides.
Partially true. If two triangles are similar, you know that the corresponding angle measures are the same.
So, you can show that the scale factor is the same for corresponding side lengths. However, you need to find the multiplier from one shape to the other using the ratio of the sides.
Sam's Claim If you know the perimeter of one shape, you can predict the perimeter of a similar shape.

Correct. As you can see in the similar rectangles J and L, when the width and length of rectangles grow by 2, the perimeters also grow by 2. So, if you know the perimeter of one shape and if you know the scale factor of the similar shape, then you can predict the perimeter of the similar shape. The perimeter is a length, so it behaves like the width and length.

supports.text: How can you find the scale factor if you used rubber bands to make similar figures?
How can you find the scale factor if you used coordinate graphs to make similar figures?

text: How can you decide if two shapes are similar? How can you determine the scale factor between two similar shapes?
To determine is two shapes are similar:

• Corresponding angles must have the same measure.
  • Corresponding sides must change by the same multiplier. The name of the multiplier is “scale factor”.

Scale factor can be determined by measuring and comparing corresponding lengths between two figures. This done using proportional reasoning. For every unit of length in the original there are x times as many units in the corresponding side length.
We have seen scale factor as the number of rubber bands used, the percent increase on a copy machine, or the coefficient relationship of the x and y coordinates.
Problem 2.3 Mouthing Off and Nosing Around: Scale Factors

In the Initial Challenge students continue to work with the Wump family as they investigate side lengths, angles, perimeters, and areas of similar rectangles and triangles. The What If Situations help solidify for students that scaled drawings/similar figures have corresponding angles that have the same measure and that corresponding sides grow or shrink by a scale factor.
How can you decide if two shapes are similar? How can you determine the scale factor between two similar shapes?
Introduce the vocabulary of scale factor and connect it to the work from previous Problems.
Tell the class that the challenge is to use the criteria of corresponding angles and side lengths to determine which rectangles (mouths) and which triangles (noses) are similar.
As the students work in pairs, look for students who are having trouble sorting out corresponding sides when finding side lengths.

Urge students to organize their work. They can record their measurements on the figures. If they use a chart, they will need some way to distinguish the sides (such as “vertical” and “horizontal” or “base” and “height”).
If some students finish early, encourage them to draw two more rectangles—one that is similar to the Wump family’s mouth and one that is not similar. Repeat for triangles.

• Have you considered the corresponding angles?
  • How might you compare corresponding side lengths?
How can you find the scale factor if you used a rubber band stretcher? Coordinate graphs?
