During the Initial Challenge take note of the strategies that students are using to find the scale factor. How are students providing evidence for the similar figures in the Initial Challenge? Do they measure all angles and sides? Are some students informally seeing that angle alone for triangles can determine similarity? For the rectangles are they ignoring the right angles and only looking at the side lengths. During the What If listen for how students describe the ideas using proportional reasoning to find a scale factor.

Discuss the answers. Ask for explanations. For rectangles J and L, students may talk about the width growing by 2 and the length growing by 2. The perimeters also grow by a factor of 2. This gives you an opportunity to help students describe the growth in different ways. We say that the widths, lengths, and perimeters grow by a scale factor of 2.

• How can you decide if two figures are similar?
  • Do you agree with Mia that you can use ratios (proportional reasoning) to show that the scale factor is the same for corresponding side lengths? Why or why not?
  • I want to grow a new Wump from Wump 1 (Mug). The scale factor is 9. What are the dimensions and perimeter of the new Wump’s mouth?
  • If the scale factor is 75, what are the measurements of the new mouth?
  • Why does the perimeter grow the same way as the lengths of the sides of a rectangle?
  • Let’s go in the reverse direction. How can you find the scale factor from the original to the image if all you have are the dimensions of the two similar figures?
  • For similar rectangles, the perimeter of the image is the scale factor times the perimeter of the original rectangle. Do you think this is true for similar triangles?
  • If the perimeter of the mouth of a new Wump family member is 150, what are the length, width, and area of its mouth? What scale factor was used to grow this new Wump from Mug 1?
  • What scale factor is needed to produce a new mouth (rectangle) whose perimeter is 5?
  • Which mouth belongs to Mug? Zug? Bug? Glug? Lug? How do you know?
  • Which nose belongs to Mug? Zug? Bug? Glug? Lug? How do you know?
As you finish the mathematical discussions, have students reflect on the Now What Do You Know question(s).

investigations.title: SAS Investigation 3 Scaling Perimeter and Area

problems.title: SAS 3.1 Using Proportional Reasoning to Rep-tile
problems.subtitle: The Area Connection

text: In Shapes and Designs, we learned that some polygons fit together to cover, or tile, a flat surface. For example, the surface of a honeycomb has a pattern of regular hexagons. Many bathroom and kitchen floors are covered with a pattern of square tiles. These patterns of polygons that fit together are called tessellations.

Look closely at the pattern of squares. We can see that the large square consists of nine small squares. The large square is similar to each of the nine small squares. The large square has sides formed by the sides of three small squares, so the scale factor from the small square to the large square is 3.

tiles.title: Similar squares with a scale factor of 3 or 1/3

text: We can also put four small squares together to make a four-tile square. This four-tile square is similar to both the large nine-tile square and the small single-tile square.

tiles.title: Similar squares with a scale factor of 2 or 1/2

text: The scale factor from the single-tile square to the four-tile square is 2. The scale factor from the four-tile square to the single-tile square is 1/2.
No matter how closely we look at the hexagon pattern, however, you cannot find a large hexagon made up of similar smaller hexagons.

A shape is a rep-tile if you can put together copies that are the same size and shape (congruent) copies of the shape to make a larger, similar shape. The copies may be rotated in order to fit together. A square is a rep-tile. In this problem we will investigate which rectangles and triangles are rep-tiles.
The Art Club at P.I. Middle school is also exploring similar figures to create rep-tiles. They need to know which rectangles and triangles are rep-tiles.
To answer this question, sketch or use your Shape Set to make several larger and similar copies of each of the following shapes:
* Which shapes are a rep-tile? Make a sketch to show how the copies fit together.

All rectangles and parallelograms have copies that can fit together to make a larger shape that is similar to the original. Also, there are some trapezoids that have copies that can fit together to make a larger, similar shape. Not every trapezoid is a rep-tile. Possible sketches are below.
All triangles have copies that can fit together to make a larger, similar triangle. Possible sketches shown below.

For the shapes that rep-tile, what is the
  • Scale factor from the original figure to the image? Explain your reasoning.
  • How does the perimeter of the larger figure relate to the perimeter of the original figure?
  • How does the area of the larger figure relate to the area of the original figure?

The side lengths and perimeter of the larger figure are the scale factor times the side lengths of the smaller figure. Note: The perimeter change can be explained by the Distributive Property. The scale factor multiplies by every length.
So, if we have a rectangle with length of L, width of W, and scale factor of s, then the perimeter change is s(L) + s(L) + s(W) + s(W) = s(L + L + S + S).
The angle measures don’t change since corresponding angles for similar figures are congruent. The corresponding angles would all have equal measures.
The corresponding angles would all have equal measures.

The area of the larger figure is the square of the scale factor, or scale factor time scale factor, times the area of the smaller figure. For example, if you have a scale factor of 5, each length would be 5 times larger. To make the reptile, you would need 25 copies of the original. The area grows by the square of the scale factor, or 52, so you need 25 copies. If we consider a rectangle with a scale factor of 5, then the area of the image would be 5L.
See the impact of scale factor on area: 5²・L・W
Examine each claim. Is it correct? Explain why.
Patricia’s Claim If it takes nine copies of a certain rectangle or triangle to make a similar figure, the scale factor is 9.

Not correct. If it takes 9 copies of a figure to make a rep-tile, then the scale factor is 3. Since the area grows by the square of the scale factor, then the scale factor must be 3 since 3•3 or 32 is 9. Note: For students who have already been exposed to the idea of square root, the following equation can also be referenced: square root 9 = 3.
Pete’s Claim If you are given a certain rectangle or triangle and a scale factor of 5, then it will take 5 copies of the original to make a scale copy.

Not correct. If we consider a rectangle, both the length and the width will increase by a factor of 5. You will need 25 copies of the original. The area grows by the scale factor times the scale factor, or square of the scale factor, so you need 25 copies.

It is true that all triangles are rep-tiles. You can subdivide any triangle into four congruent triangles, each of which is similar to the larger triangle. You can do this by finding the midpoint of each side of the triangle and then connecting the midpoints to form four smaller triangles. Each smaller triangle will be similar to the larger triangle. This can be extended to more scale factors by subdividing the sides into even smaller equal segments, then connecting these points so that the connecting lines are parallel.

Kazuko’s Claim If you want to show two triangles with the same angle measures are similar, you can use a unit rep-tile. I used an equilateral triangle whose side lengths are one unit. To show that the following two triangles are similar.

tiles.title: Kazuko’s Claim: Measuring corresponding angles using a unit rep-tile

text: It is true. We can use a unit rep-tile to show that corresponding angles are the same measure. Note that this strategy may be more difficult to use if scale factors are not whole numbers.

tiles.title: Measuring corresponding angles using a unit rep-tile

text:
Dola started with a sketch of a quadrilateral. She divided it into four smaller quadrilaterals that have the same size and shape (congruent). She claims they are similar.
  1. Explain why the smaller shapes are similar to the original.
  2. How do the lengths, perimeter, and area of the original figure compare to one of the four smaller figures?
  3. Would this work for triangles? Explain.

The smaller shapes have corresponding angles with the same measure. The corresponding lengths have all changed in the same way. We can see that two of the smaller lengths will equal the length of the corresponding side of the original.
2. The lengths, which includes the perimeters, are ½ the size of the original and areas are ¼ of the original.
3. Yes. Many find it more difficult to sub-divide triangles. You can begin by sub-dividing the side lengths. Then draw in the smaller triangles making sure you keep the corresponding sides parallel.

tiles.title: Subdividing sides of a triangle to create 4 rep-tiles

text: Then draw in the smaller triangles making sure you keep the corresponding sides parallel.

tiles.title: Subdividing sides of a triangle with parallel lines
Subdividing sides of a triangle to create 9 rep-tiles

text: How do rep-tiles show the relationship between the scale factor and the perimeter of a similar shape? What about the scale factor and the area?

When rep-tiling, we can use multiple tiles of a shape to make a larger or smaller similar shape. Rep-tiles keep the corresponding angles the same measure. This lets us focus on the relationships in the other measures, like lengths and area.

If you make a rep-tile using four same copies, then the area of a rep-tile is four times the area of the original copy. And the scale factor is 2, because the side length of a rep-tile will be twice the side length of the original copy.

If the scale factor is k, then the side lengths of the image will be times the side lengths of the original copy. Each dimension of the shape is stretched or shrunk by the scale factor. Since we find area by multiplying both dimensions, we also multiply the scale factor times the scale factor on the image. The area of the rep-tile will be times larger. If
A scale factor k = K • L • K• W =
Note that students will need to use their knowledge of the Commutative Property from the previous unit.

tiles.title: Did You Know?: Tiling and crystals

text: Problem 3.1 Using Proportional Reasoning to Rep-tile: The Area Connection

This Problem challenges students to find ways of putting multiple copies of a figure together to make a larger, similar figure. This process is called rep‑tiling. Rep‑tiling allows students to revisit similarity in a new context. In the Initial Challenge, students decide how to put rep‑tiles together and identify relationships between the scale factor, side lengths, and areas of similar figures. The What If Situations will look at student claims to synthesize these ideas.
How do rep-tiles show the relationship between the scale factor and the perimeter and area of similar shape?

In the previous Investigation, students explored the relationship between the corresponding sides, corresponding angles, perimeters, and areas of similar figures. This Problem continues students’ exploration of scale factors and similarity by rep-tiling, or building shapes from copies of smaller, similar shapes with a focus on the area change. In each of these contexts, students study how the areas of two similar figures are related to the scale factor.

Creating the rep-tiles takes time for students to cut, manipulate and draw. It may take 1.5 days to complete this task. Having a conversation after students have completed the Initial Challenge can help them focus their thinking between the two class periods.
Use the diagrams in the student edition.

• How are these patterns similar?
  • What is different about these patterns that might make one a rep‑tile and the other not?

Students work with quadrilaterals and triangles. The challenge is to determine which types of quadrilaterals and triangles are rep‑tiles. For each shape, find whether it is possible to put together several identical small shapes to form a larger version of the same shape. When it is possible, you will sketch how the shapes fit together and answer some questions about the measurements of the figures.

Some teachers have students make a poster with each rep‑tile the group finds. They display these posters as a handy reference for future discussions about the relationship between area and scale factor.

To scaffold for students who need some suggestions to move forward you can suggest that they can systematically explore the possibilities. Point out that it is reasonable to assume that edges with the same length must be placed together.

You might ask students if they have checked angle measures. Some may use a transparent piece of paper to copy and compare. Others may use angle rulers or protractors. Students should notice that corresponding angles are congruent. They need to make sure that the angles they are comparing are corresponding.

Listen to students as they are discussing the shapes that would rep-tile in the Initial Challenge. Find student work examples to highlight the scale factor and area change relationship to use in the Summary. Listen to how students reason through the student claims in the What If Situations. Use their responses to frame your summary

You can have different groups of students display their rep‑tiles during the Summarize. Students can use their copies of use Learning Aid 3.1C: Rep-tile Recording Sheet or a large classroom poster during a gallery walk to draw some conclusions. Students should look at the displayed rep‑tiles and record any new information or questions they have about rep‑tiles. Groups can share their observations, but be sure they provide explanations.

• Do you have any What If questions?
  • How does the side of the smaller quadrilateral or triangle compare to the side of the larger figure?
  • How do the angles of the original quadrilateral or triangle compare to the angles of the rep‑tile figure?
  • How many original shapes are needed to cover the rep-tile?
  • How many smaller rectangles do I need to make the next larger rep‑tile figure?
  • Predict what will happen for the next rep‑tile figure.
  • What pattern do you see when extending the rep‑tile figures?
  • What do you know about the relationship of scale factor and area change for two similar figures?
As you finish the mathematical discussions, have students reflect on the Now What Do You Know question(s).

problems.title: SAS 3.2 Designing Under Constraints
problems.subtitle: Scale Factors and Similar Shapes (Scale Drawings)

text: The scale factor provides information about how side lengths, perimeters and areas of the figures are related. It

• Is the ratio of an image side length to the corresponding side length of the original.
  • is the multiplier that connects the original length to the image length.
  • tells us how one length grows or shrinks by a certain factor.
In Problem 3.2, we use scale drawings to make similar shapes given a set of constraints (criteria).

The Art Club created several design challenges using Rectangle A and Triangle B.
  • Use the design criteria as a guide to draw a new similar rectangle.
  • Describe the lengths, perimeters, and areas for each figure.
• Rectangle P The scale factor from Rectangle A to Rectangle P is 2.5.

To make the new Rectangle P that is similar to A, multiply the scale factor, 2.5, by each side length of rectangle A. The size of rectangle A is 4 x 8. So, you can get 4 x 2.5 = 10, 8 x 2.5 =20, which becomes a 10 x 20 rectangle. The lengths are 2.5 times larger. The perimeter increases from 24 units to 60 units. This is an increase of 2.5 times. 24 • 2.5 = 60. The area increases from 32 square units to 200 square units. This is an increase of 6.25 times. 32 • 6.25 = 200. Using the Commutative Property, we can see that the area of P is (2.5 • 4) • (2.5 • 8) = 2.5 • 2.5 • 4 • 8 = 6.25 • 32.

tiles.title: Comparing Rectangle A and Rectangle P

text: * **Rectangle Q** The perimeter of Rectangle Q is three times the perimeter of Rectangle A.

If the perimeter of the new rectangle 3 is three times the perimeter of A, each side length of Rectangle Q will be three times the corresponding side length of A. We will have 4 x 3 = 12, 8 x 3 = 24, which becomes a 12 x 24 rectangle.

tiles.title: Comparing Rectangle A and Rectangle Q

text: The lengths are 3 times larger. The perimeter increases from 24 units to72 units. This is an increase of 3 times. 24 • 3 = 72. The area increases from 32 square units to 288 square units. This is an increase of 9 times. 32 • 9 = 288. Using the Commutative Property, we can see that the area of P is (3 • 4) • (3 • 8) = 3 • 3 • 4 • 8 = 9 • 32.
* **Rectangle R** The area of Rectangle R is 1/4 the area of Rectangle A.

If the new Rectangle R is ¼ the area of the rectangle A, there are four congruent Rectangle Rs in the rectangle A. To divide the rectangle A into four of them, you should divide each side length of the rectangle A into two. So, the side lengths of the rectangle R are 2 and 4.

tiles.title: Comparing Rectangle A and Rectangle R

text: The lengths are ½ the size of the original. The perimeter decreases from 24 units to 12 units. This is decrease of 0.5 times. 24 • 0.5 = 12. The area decreases from 32 square units to 8 square units. The new area is ¼ of the original. 32 • ¼  = 8. Using the Commutative Property, we can see that the area of P is (½ • 4) • (½ • 8) = ½ • ½ • 4 • 8 = ¼ • 32.
For each part, draw a triangle similar to Triangle B that fits the given description. Explain your reasoning.
**Triangle X** The area of the Triangle X is 16 times the area of Triangle B.

If the new Rectangle R is ¼ the area of the rectangle A, there are four congruent Rectangle Rs in the rectangle A. To divide the rectangle A into four of them, you should divide each side length of the rectangle A into two. So, the side lengths of the rectangle R are 2 and 4.

tiles.title: Comparing Triangle B and Triangle X

text: **Triangle Y** The scale factor from Triangle B to Triangle X is 1/2.
For the triangle B, the base length is 7 and the height is 4. Using the scale factor ½ to make a similar triangle X, the base length of the Triangle Y will be 3.5 and the height will be 2.

tiles.title: Comparing Triangle B and Triangle Y

text: **Triangle Z** The ratio of corresponding side lengths of Triangle B to Triangle Z is 2:3.

When the ratio of corresponding side lengths from Triangle B to Triangle Z is 2:3, the scale factor will be 3/2. For every length of 2 on Triangle B, we would have a length of 3 on Triangle Z. This means that the side increase 1.5 times. The base length of the Triangle Z will be 7 x 1.5 = 10.5 and the height of the Triangle 3 will be 4 x 1.5 = 6.

tiles.title: Comparing Triangle B and Triangle Z

supports.text: How do you find the scale factor between two similar figures?
If the scale factor from one shape to the other is 2, how do corresponding sides, perimeters, areas, and angles change from the original figure to its image?
What is the area of Rectangle A? What is the perimeter of Rectangle A?

text:
Situation A. Similar Rectangles

These two rectangles are similar. Is it possible to find the length of side AD? Explain your reasoning.

tiles.title: Similar rectangles with an unknown side length

text: 4cm. Side AD corresponds to side EH, and side CD corresponds to side EF.

tiles.title: Sample diagram using scale factor to find an unknown side length

text:
Situation B. Similar Triangles

These two triangles are similar. Find all the missing side lengths and angles. Explain your reasoning.

The scale factor from one figure to the other is 7.5 ÷ 6, or 1.25. Side DF is 3.75 cm since 3 × 1.25 is 3.75. Side FE is 6.25 cm (5 × 1.25 = 6.25). Because the triangles are similar, the corresponding angle measures are the same. So, the measure of angle F is 94°. Angle B and corresponding angle E are each 30° since 180 – (94 + 56) = 30. Note: Students will need to use the fact that the sum of the interior angles of a triangle is 180°.

tiles.title: Similar triangles with unknown side lengths and angles
Sample diagram using scale factor to find unknown side lengths and angles

supports.text: Can using corresponding sides help?
Can using corresponding angles help?
What is the scale factor from one shape to the other?

text:
How can you use scale factors to draw similar figures(scale drawings)? 

How can you use scale factors to find missing information about angles measures? Side lengths? Area? Perimeter?

With lengths of similar figures, you can multiply each length of the original figure by the scale factor to get the corresponding length on the image. Keeping all the angle measures the same as the original, you can draw the similar figures.
To find missing information about angles, you do not need to use scale factors because the corresponding angle measures of similar figures stay the same as the original.

To find missing information about area, you can use scale factors. When the scale factor from the original to the similar figure is *x*, the area of the similar figure will be *x* times *x* or *x^2* times the area of the original.

Perimeter is the sum of lengths. So, every relationship for length and scale factor is the same for perimeter and scale factor. To find missing information about perimeter, you can use scale factors. When the scale factor from the original to the similar figure is *x*, the perimeter of the similar figure will be *x* times the perimeter of the original perimeter.
Problem 3.2 Designing Under Constraints: Scale Factors and Similar Shapes (Scale Drawings)

In this Problem, students use scale factors or other information to make figures that are similar to a specific triangle or rectangle. In the Initial Challenge students will create new shapes from original shapes to match given criteria. In the What If Situations students find missing side lengths and angle measures in pairs of similar figures.
How can you use scale factors to draw similar figures (scale drawings)?
How can you use scale factors to find missing information about angles measures? Side lengths? Area? Perimeter?
In this Problem, students continue to build on their understanding of scale factors and scaled drawings or similarity.

• If you are given a rectangle, how might you draw a similar rectangle with a scale factor of 2?
  • How would the areas of the original rectangle and the rectangle you drew relate?
  • What would the scale factor be for a pair of similar figures where one figure has an area 16 times as great as the other figure?
  • What is the base of a triangle?
  • What is the height of a triangle?
Display Rectangle A and Triangle B for the class. Tell the class that their challenge is to draw similar figures with the conditions given in the Problem.

• What are the side lengths of Rectangle A?
  • What is the area of Rectangle A?
  • What is the area of Triangle B?
Assign one or two from each set in the Initial Challenge to partner groups. Have students create posters to present their findings.

Check to make sure that students are identifying the correct scale factor in the parts that give information about area. For example, in the Initial Challenge and Triangle X, if the area of the sketched figure must be 16 times the area of the original figure, students must understand that the area grows by the square of the scale factor. So, in this case, the scale factor is 4.

• Can using corresponding sides help you?
  • Can using corresponding angles help you?
  • What is the scale factor from one shape to the other?
  • What do we know about the relationship between scale factor and area change?

As you are circulating during the summary select student work from the design criteria in the Initial Challenge to use for the summary discussion- select work that is correct and incorrect to help students work on justifying their ideas about scale factor and area relationships. Choose examples from the What If Situations to discuss how to use scale factor to find missing side lengths.
As students present their solutions, be sure they explain their reasoning and methods.

• What does a whole number scale factor do to change a shape?
  • What does a fractional scale factor do to change a shape?
  • How did you draw _____?
  • How did scale factor help you to draw _____?
  • What is the relationship between scale factor and area?
  • How did you find the missing side lengths in the What If Situations?
As you finish the mathematical discussions, have students reflect on the Now What Do You Know question(s).
In this problem we will use similar triangles to find the distance across a river from Stake 1 to Tree 1.

Durrell, Angie, and Tonya are designing a boardwalk that crosses a river for a science project. They make several measurements and use stakes to mark the distances to create triangles. They also make a sketch like the diagram below.

The students use similar triangles to find distances that are difficult to measure. The diagram shows a specific type of similar triangles, nested triangles, which are triangles that share a common angle.
•  What is the distance across the river from Stake 1 to Tree 1? Explain your reasoning.

tiles.title: Diagram of the river with similar triangles

text: The triangles in the diagram are similar.
The angles that look like right angles are right angles.
The angle at Stake 3 is shared by both triangles.

90ft. The distance from Tree 1 to Tree 2 is 140 ft. and the corresponding side length of the smaller triangle is 80 ft. Then the scale factor from the small triangle to the large one is 1.75 (80 × 1.75 = 140). This would make the distance from Stake 3 to Tree 1 is 210 ft (120 × 1.75 = 210), the distance across the river from Stake 1 to Tree 1 is 90 ft. (210 – 120 = 90)

supports.text: What shapes do you see in the diagram? Are they similar? Why?
What measurements in the diagram might be useful?
How can corresponding sides and angles in two similar triangles help find the missing measurements?

text:
Situation A. Durrell's Claim

I used unit rep-tiles to show that the smaller right triangle is similar to the larger right triangle. Is he correct? Explain.

Students may refer back to Problem 3.1 Kazuko’s Claim. The scale factor is not a whole number. So, we cannot consider the smaller triangle as a unit rep-tile. The distance from Stake 1 to Stake 2 in smaller triangle is 80ft. The corresponding distance in larger triangle is 140ft (from Tree 1 to Tree 2). If you put two small triangles, it will be 160 ft long, which is longer than 140 ft. You cannot fit whole amounts of the small triangles in the large triangle. Therefore, you cannot use rep-tiles to show the similarity.
I put the stakes in different places and made a sketch. It does not change my answer.

tiles.title: Another Diagram of the river with similar triangles

text: Yes, the distance will be the same. The scale factor from the small to the large triangle is 4. This gives the distance between Stake 3 and Tree 1 as 120 ft. From this, we subtract the 30 ft from Stake 3 to Stake 1 to get 90 ft across the river. In this case, you can use rep-tiles because you can fit 16 small triangles into the large triangle.

supports.text: How is the new diagram in the What If? section different from the diagram in the initialChallenge? How is it the same?

text: How can you use similar triangles to find a distance that is difficult to measure?

To find a distance that you cannot measure directly, you can use similar figures. Draw a diagram that includes a pair of similar nested triangles. One of the sides of the similar triangles should be the distance that you are having trouble measuring. You can multiply (or divide) one side length in a triangle by the scale factor to find the corresponding side length (the missing length) in a similar triangle.
Problem 3.3 Out of Reach: Finding Lengths with Similar Triangles

In this Problem, students use similar triangles to measure distances on the ground that cannot be measured directly. In the Initial Challenge students look at a finding the distance across a river using nested triangles. The What If Situations have students refine their thinking about using similar triangles, and the scale factor between the triangles, to find unknown corresponding lengths.
How can you use similar triangles to find a distance that is difficult to measure?

Describe the Problem to the class. Ask students to compare the ideas to Problem 3.2. Have the class identify the similar triangles and find the corresponding angles and sides. You may want to introduce the term nested in the Launch for this Problem to describe the two triangles pictured in Problem 3.3 in the Student Edition.
Have students use the diagram to find the distance across the river. Make sure they provide explanations for their methods.

In general, it is true that if the corresponding angles of two triangles are congruent, then the triangles are similar. In this Unit, we assume that this theorem is true. A proof for the theorem is developed in 8th grade.
Be sure the groups have identified the similar triangles and the corresponding sides and angles they need to measure.

  • What is the scale factor between the smaller triangle and the larger triangle in the Initial Challenge?
Look for examples of how students use scale factor to find missing sides lengths.

When all groups have made their calculations, give each group a chance to share their work. If there are a variety of answers, ask the class why groups arrived at different answers. See if students can explain to others how to correct their work. This is a good opportunity to discuss accuracy and attending to precision with the class.

investigations.title: SAS Investigation 4 Similar Figures and Ratios

problems.title: SAS 4.1 Equivalent Ratios within Similar Figures

text: We can enhance a report or story by adding photographs, drawings, or diagrams. If we place a graphic in an electronic document, we can enlarge, reduce, or move it. When we click on the graphic, it appears inside a frame with handles along the sides, such as the figure shown below.
We can change the size and shape of the image by dragging the handles.
How did this technique produce these variations of the original shape? Which of these images appears to be similar to the original? Why?

Recall from our work in the Comparing Quantities unit that a ratio is a comparison of two quantities such as two lengths. The rectangle around the original photo is about 10 centimeters tall and 8 centimeters wide. We can say
For every 10 cm of height there are 8 cm of width.
The ratio of height to width is 10 to 8.
This table gives the ratios of height to width for the images.

tiles.title: What do you notice about the height-to-width ratios?

text: The comparisons “10cm to 8cm” and “5cm to 4cm” are equivalent ratios. We can scale the ratio 10 to 8 down by multiplying each quantity by 1/2. Or we could scale the ratio 5 to 4 up by multiplying each quantity by 2.

Equivalent ratios are like equivalent fractions. In fact, ratios are often written in fraction form. You can express equivalent ratios with equations. A proportion is an equation stating that two ratios are equal.
For every 10 cm of height there are 8 cm of width
For every 8 cm of width there are 10 cm in height or 8 to 10.
How can you express this in fraction form?
What information does each ratio written in fraction fraction form represent in the similar figures?
For the set of figures of the student holding the fish, the original figure is similar to the figure on the right. Notice that the ratios are equal.
We know that a scale factor relates each length in a figure to the corresponding length in its image. In this problem we will explore ratios of adjacent side lengths within figures.
For the diagrams in this problem, all measurements are drawn to scale unless otherwise noted.

tiles.title: Rectangles A, B, C, and D

text: • For the set of rectangles, which are similar? Why?
Rectangles: A, B, and C are similar.
Because the shapes are rectangles, all the angles will be 90˚. So, corresponding angles will have the same measures.
To determine similarity of these rectangles, students may use scale factors or ratios.
Rectangle A: (12 short side)/(20 long side) = (3 short side)/(5 long side) = (0.6 short side)/(1 long side)
Rectangle B: (6 short side)/(10 long side) = (3 short side)/(5 long side) = (0.6 short side)/(1 long side)
Rectangle C: (9 short side)/(15 long side) = (3 short side)/(5 long side) = (0.6 short side)/(1 long side)
Rectangle D: (6 short side)/(20 long side) = (3 short side)/(10 long side) = (0.3 short side)/(1 long side)
The ratio of the length of the short side to the length of the long side is the same for all three similar rectangles. The rectangle that is not similar to the others has a different ratio.
If the scale factors for both length and width are equivalent, two rectangles are similar.

tiles.title: Scale factors for similar Rectangles A, B, and C

text: If the scale factors for both length and width are equivalent, two rectangles are similar.

Note: If figures are similar, their ratios of corresponding side lengths will be equivalent. The ratio of adjacent side lengths within a figure gives an indication of the shape of the original figure (and image) since it compares measures within one figure. The ratio of side lengths is not enough to know of a figure is scaled, corresponding angles measures must be equivalent.
After finding scale factors like those in this Problem, many students will discuss the advantages of finding the ratio of the adjacent side lengths for measurements like these.

• If two rectangles are similar, write as many ratios as possible of adjacent side lengths in one rectangle compared to the corresponding adjacent side lengths in the other rectangle. What do you notice?
The ratios of adjacent sides of similar figures are equivalent.

Situation A. Similar Triangle

Students in Ms. Kelly’s class used different strategies to decide which of the following triangles were similar. Examine each strategy. Is it correct? Explain why.

tiles.title: Triangles A, B, C, and D

text: If two triangles are similar, then corresponding angles are equal.
So, I found the angles of each triangle.
Triangles A, C, and D have corresponding equal angles. I checked the corresponding ratio of adjacent sides and found that they were equal.
So, triangles A, C, and D are similar.

Triangles: A, C, and D are similar. The corresponding angle measures of those triangles are congruent. (Note: Students have to use the fact that the sum of the angle measures in a triangle is 180˚. More exact measures of the angles for the triangles are 29.99˚, 61.02˚, and 88.98˚.)
Ratio of adjacent side lengths – longest side to short side lengths:
The unit rate of the length of one side to the length of an adjacent side is equivalent for all three similar triangles. The triangle that is not similar to the others has a different rate.
I found the scale factor for corresponding sides.
The scale factor from triangle A to triangle C is 3/2 or 1.5. That is, we can multiple a side length of triangle A by 1.5 to get the side length of the corresponding side length in Triangle C.
We can also say the scale factor from triangle C to A is 2/3 or 0.666…
Since each side is scaled up by the same scale factor triangles A and C are similar.
I used this method to show that triangle A is similar to triangle D. So, A, C, and D are similar triangles.
Triangles: A, C, and D are similar.
The corresponding angle measures of those triangles are congruent.
Note: Students have to use the fact that the sum of the angle measures in a triangle is 180˚. More exact measures of the angles for the triangles are 29.99˚, 61.02˚, and 88.98˚.

tiles.title: Scale factors for similar Triangles A, C, and D

I can use the ratio of adjacent sides to find the distance across the river in Problem 3.3.

What information do the ratios of adjacent side lengths within two similar figures provide about similar figures? How are these ratios helpful in solving problems?

If two shapes have corresponding angles with the same measure and the ratios of adjacent side lengths are equivalent, the shapes are similar. If the ratios of corresponding adjacent side lengths are equal, the multiplicative relationship is the same which means the shape lengths are scaled in the same way.
These ratios are helpful when you find missing side lengths related to two similar figures.

In Problem 4.1, students find a ratio for adjacent side lengths within a figure. In the Initial Challenge students compare this ratio to the ratio for adjacent sides in corresponding positions within another figure. In the What If Situations they recognize that, these ratios are equivalent for similar figures.
What information do the ratios of adjacent side lengths within two similar figures provide about similar figures? How are these ratios helpful in solving problems?
Students extend their notions of similarity of triangles from previous Investigations to similarity of rectangles. Specifically, they explore the ratios of adjacent sides of rectangles.

By comparing their ideas about similar triangles to other similar figures, such as rectangles, students deepen their understanding of similarity. For example, two rectangles can have congruent corresponding angles but not be similar. This is not true for triangles.
Tell students that they will look at sets of quadrilaterals and triangles to determine if they are similar. They will use scale factors and ratios of adjacent sides to determine similarity.

As you circulate, check to make sure that students are writing correct ratios for each rectangle and for each triangle. You can hand out copies of Learning Aid 4.1D: Ratio Recording Sheet if your students would benefit from using a table to organize their work. Provide any necessary help in keeping track of the place of corresponding measures in the ratios. The numerators of each ratio need to relate corresponding lengths, and the denominators of each ratio need to relate corresponding lengths.

Students should label their work in some way, such as length to width or width to length. Students need to be consistent in what they consider to be the width or length in terms of which one is the long side, and which one is the short side on rectangles and parallelograms.
As you are circulating during the Explore, look for students making sense of using ratios and connecting this reasoning with their understanding of scale factors.

Discuss which figures were similar in the Initial Challenge. Be sure that students name corresponding side lengths in the numerators of the ratios, and that they name corresponding side lengths in the denominators of the ratios.
Students should compare the ratios for both similar and non-similar figures. This is an opportunity to review or assess their understanding of equivalence.

• Are all rectangles similar?
  • We used ratios of short side to long side on the quadrilaterals. What if we had used long side to short side? Would this still give us the same answers on which ones are similar?
  • Describe the criteria that are necessary for two parallelograms to be similar.
  • What are the ratios of shortest side to longest side for each of the similar triangles you chose?
  • What do you notice about those ratios?
  • What is the scale factor from the smaller triangle to the larger triangle?
  • How does the scale factor relate to the proportions of the ratios of adjacent sides?
  • How can you find the missing angle measure?
  • Choose a pair of similar figures. What is the scale factor?
  • How does the method you used to find scale factor relate to the ratio of corresponding sides in two similar figures?
As you finish the mathematical discussions, have students reflect on the Now What Do You Know question(s).

problems.title: SAS 4.2 Using Shadows and Mirrors to Find Heights

text: In the last Problem you found two ways to find missing lengths in pairs of similar figures.

Scale Factor method

Use the ratio of corresponding side lengths across each figure to find the scale factor. Use scale factor to find the missing lengths.

OR

Ratios of Side Lengths within Figures method

Use the ratios of adjacent side lengths with each figure. The ratios have the same unit rate.

In Problem 3.3, we found the distance across a river using similar triangles. We can find the height of a school building by climbing a ladder and using a long tape measure. We can also use easier and less dangerous ways to find the height. In the next Problem we will find the height of an object using similar triangles.
Below are descriptions for two experiments that can help us find the height of an object using similar triangles.

One method for finding heights of objects is called the “mirror method”. Ashton’s class experiments with the mirror method. They want to understand how it works. They use it to measure the height of their principal. From science class, they knew that light reflects off a mirror at the same angle (angle of reflection) at which it hits the mirror (angle of incidence). This creates two similar right triangles.
On a sunny day, any upright object casts a shadow. A middle school class used the shadow method to measure the Statue of Liberty. The diagram shows two triangles.
The triangles sides are the height of the object, the length of the objects shadow, and the side connecting these two points. This creates two similar right triangles.

The triangles are scaled. The angles located at the mirror are congruent. If we imagined flipping the triangle created by the distance from the mirror to Ashton, we can see the triangles are similar. These triangles look like the ones that we created with the rep-tiles and with measuring the river distance.

tiles.title: Diagram showing similar triangles in the mirror method

text: The statue and the stick are at a right angle to the ground. Another angle is formed by the sun and the ground. For two nearby points at a common time, the sun appears at the same angle, making these corresponding angles congruent. The third angle must be the same in each triangle since all three interior angles of a triangle must add to 180 degrees.

The length of the shadow depends on the height of the object. The shadow of the taller object will be longer. The stick and its shadow are two legs of the right triangle, and the statue and its shadow also form a right triangle. These two triangles are similar. You can compare the lengths of shadows, and then you will get the scale factor. Then you can find the height of the statue using the scale factor and the length of the stick.
• What is the height of the principal? The height of the Statue of Liberty?
72 inches from the floor to the principal’s eyes.

tiles.title: Sample reasoning to find the principal’s height

text: We cannot tell the height of the statue without knowing the measurements. To find the height, we can compare the lengths of shadows to get the scale factor. Then you can find the height of the statue using the scale factor and the length of the stick.
Statue shadow ÷ stick shadow → gives scale factor
Scale factor • height of stick → height of statue
1. Use the mirror method to find the height of a tall object in your school.

• Mirror
  • Measuring tool such as a meter stick, yard stick, or measuring tape
  • Something tall or high on a wall to measure, such as a flagpole, top of a building, or something near the ceiling of a tall room
  • Pencil and Paper

• Set the mirror on the floor. Backup until you can see the object you want to measure in the mirror.
  • Make the three necessary measurements:You will need to know:

1. how far the mirror is away from the object,
  2. how far the mirror is from the person looking into the mirror, and
  3. the height from the floor to the person’s eyes.
Note that you will need to form two right triangles.

• Sketch a diagram and record your measurements on the sketch.
  • Use the similar triangles and your sketch to find the height of the object.
2. Use the shadow method to find the height of a tall object near your school.

• Meter stick or yard stick
  • Measuring tool such as additional meter sticks, yard sticks, or measuring tape
  • Something tall to measure, such as a flagpole or building
  • Pencil and Paper
  • Sunshine to create a shadow

• Stand the meter/yard stick at a 90˚ angle to the ground.
  • Make the three necessary measurements. You will need to know

1. the height of your stick,
  2. the length of the shadow of your stick, and
  3. the length of the shadow of your object.
Note that you will need to form two right triangles.

• Sketch a diagram and record your measurements on the sketch.
  • Use the similar triangles and your sketch to find the height of the object.
Student results will vary. The strategies give approximate measurements.

Learning to limit the variables that impact the measures takes some time and experience. Students will get “messy” data. When looking at results of groups who measured the same item, variables that impact the differences can be discussed.
The applications allow students to see a use of similarity.
Note: These strategies are used to get “indirect” measures by people working in various fields such as outside design and construction.

Situation B. Using A Camera to Find Distance

Cameras on satellites or planes are used to find distances on earth. The following figure shows a tree and its image in a camera. The two triangles created are similar.

If the height of the image is 14 mm, the focal length is 35 mm, and the distance from the object is 10 m. What is the height of the tree?

tiles.title: Labeled diagram of similar triangles created by camera lenses
Diagram of similar triangles created by camera lenses
Sample reasoning using ratio of adjacent sides

text: If two figures are similar, how can you use information about the figures to find unknown lengths, perimeters, areas, or angle measures?

For lengths and perimeters, you can use the scale factor and/or the ratio of adjacent side lengths. When two figures are similar, the ratios of corresponding adjacent side lengths will be equal. Also, when two figures are similar, the ratio of corresponding side lengths across two figures will be equal.
For areas, you can use the scale factor. When the scale factor from figure A to figure B is , the area of the figure B will be a times a, or a2 times the area of the figure A.

For angle measures, you can use the fact that the corresponding angles measures in two similar figures are equal. You can find missing angle measures by looking at corresponding angle measures in the similar figure.

Special cameras on satellites, airplanes, and ships take images of large areas on earth. They use the images to calculate lengths and areas of shapes. This process is called remote sensing. Some use of remote sensing is tracking forest fires, erupting volcanoes, ocean floor, growth of cities or forests,
Georeferencing means that the internal coordinate system of a digital map or aerial photo can be related to a ground system of geographic coordinates.
A georeferenced digital map or image has been tied to a known Earth coordinate system, so users can determine where every point on the map or aerial photo is located on the Earth's surface.

The relevant coordinate transforms are typically stored within the image file (GeoPDF and GeoTIFF are examples of georeferenced file formats), though there are many possible mechanisms for implementing georeferencing. Georeferencing in the digital file allows basic map analysis to be done, such as pointing and clicking on the map to determine the coordinates of a point, to calculate distances and areas, and to determine other information.
Problem 4.2 Using Shadows and Mirrors to Find Heights

In this Problem, students use shadows and mirror reflections to estimate the heights of real objects that are difficult to measure directly. Students recognize that the mathematics they have learned so far in this Unit is helpful for solving problems in real life. In the Initial Challenge students look at using mirrors to find the height of a principal. In the What If Situations students look at finding the height of the Statue of Liberty using shadows and how a camera lens uses similar triangles.
If two figures are similar, how can you use information about the figures to find unknown lengths, perimeters, areas, or angle measures?
If needed you can begin this Problem by having students practice one or two missing-part problems such as the one below, also displayed in Teaching Aid 4.2: Sample Missing Triangle Length.

• What do you notice about the drawing of the mirror method to find the height of the principal?

  • How do you know they are similar?
Tell students that in this problem they will look for similar figures and use them to find missing measurements.

Implementation Note: What If Situation A has two experiments. One is using the shadow method to find the height of a tall object near the school. The second experiment is using the mirror method to find the heigh of a tall object in your school. You could do one or both of these with your students.

• Would a scale factor or ratio help you find the height?
  • How is this problem similar to Problem 4.1?
  • Do your measurements seem reasonable

When students are working with the mirror method and/or shadow in What If Situation A monitor how they are making their measurements. Remind them to walk backwards until they see the reflection of the top of the object in the mirror. Assist them with measuring from end to end on the shadow.
As you are circulating during the Explore find examples of students using scale factors or ratios to find the heights of the objects. Use this student work in the summary discussion
Collect the students’ answers for each of the missing lengths.

This means that if two triangles have corresponding angles equal, then the figures are congruent and hence similar. Or you could choose to tell them that sun and shadows always produce similar triangles.

Ms. Cho’s students also made the following claims. Do you agree? Explain why.
Yes. The corresponding angles will be 90˚. For corresponding side lengths, you can always find a scale factor. Adjacent sides will always be equivalent ratios of side to side.
Yes. All circles are the same shape. Any radius can be scaled to find a corresponding radius. Any diameter can be scaled to find a corresponding diameter.
No. All of the following shapes are quadrilaterals. None of them are similar to the other.
**Sze’s Claim** All triangles are similar if their corresponding angles are equal.
Yes. If all of the angles have equivalent measures, the triangles will have the same basic shape. The corresponding side lengths can be scaled to form a similar triangle.
We saw this idea when we had reptiles.
And we used this idea when measuring the river.
**Matt’s Claim** Circles are not similar since the do not have angles or side lengths.
Circles are not polygons. However, like any other shape, circles can be scaled.
Circles have measures, such as, the radius or diameter.

Situation B. Creating More Sets

What are strategies for identifying if shapes have been scaled (similar figures) or if the shapes are imposters?
Answers will vary. There are many possible solutions. Some possible answers:

In this unit, we used proportional reasoning to solve problems involving similar figures (scale drawings). At the end of this Investigation, what do you know about similar figures? What do you know about proportional reasoning?
Proportional reasoning can be used to compare lengths, angles, and areas of similar figures. Students may discuss some of the ratio relationships between the shapes in the Investigation.
For figures with the same basic shape (similar figures), student should begin to realize that some measurement change and some stay the same.
Students should begin to use and articulate relationships between attributes, such as:
* same basic look to the shape,
* corresponding angles of an enlargement or reduction of an original figure stay the same,
Changes by the multiplier: *  side lengths of an enlargement or reduction figure, as compared to the original figure, change in size by the multiplier used with the original,
* perimeter of an enlargement or reduction figure, as compared to the original figure, change in size by the multiplier used with the original,
* area of an enlarged or reduced figure, as compared to the original figure, changed but not by the multiplier used on the original figure.

In this unit, we used proportional reasoning to solve problems involving involving similar figures (scale drawings). At the end of this Investigation, what do you know about similarity? What do you know about proportional reasoning?
With similar figures, some attributes of the shape change and some stay the same:
* corresponding angles of two similar figures are the same measure while angles of non-similar figures may not be.
* corresponding side lengths of similar figures increase or decrease by the scale factor used to create an image.
* perimeter of a new similar figure, as compared to the original figure, changes in size by the scale factor between the original and the new image.
**The relationship between corresponding sides of similar figures can be expressed as a ratio. This ratio can help us find the scale factor.**

In this unit, we used proportional reasoning to investigate reasoning to investigate similar figures also called scale drawings. At the end of this Investigation, what do you know about similarity? What do you know about proportional reasoning?
Students should express which attributes change and which stay the same when one figure is scaled to make an image:
* corresponding angles of two similar figures are the same measure while angles of non-similar figures may not be.
* corresponding side lengths and perimeter of the similar figure increases or decreases by the scale factor (multiplier).
* area of similar figures increases or decreases by the scale factor squared (multiplier squared)

In this unit, we used proportional reasoning to investigate reasoning to investigate similar figures also called scale drawings. At the end of this Investigation, what do you know about similarity? What do you know about proportional reasoning?
When scaling figures, some attributes change and some stay the same.
* corresponding angles of two similar figures are the same measure while angles of non-similar figures may not be.

*  corresponding side lengths, including perimeter, of the similar figure increases or decreases by the scale factor (multiplier). If the scale factor is larger than 1, the shape gets larger. If the scale factor is 1, the shape stays the same size. If the scale factor is smaller than 1, the shape gets smaller.
* area of similar figures increases or decreases by the scale factor squared (multiplier squared)
* ratios of corresponding adjacent side lengths within two similar figures are equal
* Proportional relationships exist between corresponding lengths of similar figures. We use the quantities within the shapes and quantities across the shapes to describe the scaling.

We use the proportional relationships to create similar figures in many ways. Some include using; pictures, rubber bands, copy machine, coordinate grid, nested triangles formed across spaces, shadows, and mirror reflections.
